From: max.smith@trading.com
To: vicente.garcia@shipping.com
Subject: Wheat Cargo Inquiry - Odessa to Barcelona
Timestamp: 2023-08-01 09:15
Body: Morning Vicente,

I have 4,300MT of wheat from Odessa to Barcelona. Could you advise if you can fit this in early August, and what's your standard demurrage clause?

Best regards,
Max

---
From: vicente.garcia@shipping.com
To: max.smith@trading.com
Subject: Re: Wheat Cargo Inquiry - Odessa to Barcelona
Timestamp: 2023-08-01 10:30
Body: Dear Max,

Yes, we can accommodate this shipment in early August. Regarding demurrage terms, we operate on standard FIOS terms (Free In/Out Stowed). Please note that your demurrage rate should match between buyer and seller. Would you like me to send you a full contract for review?

All the best,
Vicente

---
From: max.smith@trading.com
To: vicente.garcia@shipping.com
Subject: Re: Wheat Cargo Inquiry - Odessa to Barcelona
Timestamp: 2023-08-01 11:45
Body: Dear Vicente,

Thank you. I don't require the full contract, just the demurrage clause would do. We will send you the draft offer in the next two days.

Warm regards,
Max

---
From: vicente.garcia@shipping.com
To: max.smith@trading.com
Subject: Re: Wheat Cargo Inquiry - Odessa to Barcelona
Timestamp: 2023-08-01 13:20
Body: Dear Max,

Our offer would be based on the FIOS terms. Let me know if you accept and I'll send you the draft offer ASAP.

All the best,
Vicente

From: stanley.chen@etgroup.com
To: jake.mueller@hamburgsa.com
Subject: Iron Ore Shipment Inquiry - Sumatra to Suez
Timestamp: 2023-07-15 09:30
Body: Hey Jake,

Let's say we're looking to pick up 20,000MT from Sumatra to Suez around August. How about we have a four-week laycan, starting 1st August?

Any ideas about freight and duration of voyage?

Regards,
Stanley

---
From: jake.mueller@hamburgsa.com
To: stanley.chen@etgroup.com
Subject: Re: Iron Ore Shipment Inquiry - Sumatra to Suez
Timestamp: 2023-07-15 14:45
Body: Dear Mr. Chen,

Thank you for your inquiry through E&T Group regarding iron ore transport from Indonesia.

We can offer transport for 20,000mt of iron ore (Fe 62%) with a laycan from 1st August to 1st September. Loading will be from the Sumatra region.

Please note that all offers should be made on a non-negotiable basis (ex works) in USD, based on the FOB Hamburg price of iron ore (US$78/mt).

Kindly let us know if you would like to proceed with freight and sailing cost details.

Best regards,
Jake Mueller

---
From: jake.mueller@hamburgsa.com
To: stanley.chen@etgroup.com
Subject: Re: Iron Ore Shipment Inquiry - Inspection Requirements
Timestamp: 2023-07-20 11:20
Body: Dear Stanley,

Apologies for the delay. We've been addressing issues with bills of lading.

Regarding the cargo inspection at discharge port, this will need to be arranged through your broker or agent. We've removed the clause making us responsible for inspection duration from the bill of lading.

Please note that your client will be responsible for customs clearance at the discharge port. We understand you're working with our port agent on documentation, but please let us know if you need any assistance.

Best regards,
Jake

---
From: stanley.chen@etgroup.com
To: jake.mueller@hamburgsa.com
Subject: Re: Discharge Port Change - Antwerp
Timestamp: 2023-07-25 16:15
Body: Dear Jake,

I hope you're well. The client has changed the discharge port from Hamburg to Antwerp, Belgium. The cargo is already on board and sailing, so we had to sign a bill of lading without prior notification.

We will contact your agent in Antwerp to ensure proper documentation for cargo clearance.

Please send us a copy of the bill of lading when possible, and we await confirmation of the inspection schedule.

Regards,
Stanley

---
From: jake.mueller@hamburgsa.com
To: stanley.chen@etgroup.com
Subject: Re: Cargo Clearance Confirmation
Timestamp: 2023-07-26 17:30
Body: Hi Stanley,

Our agent in Antwerp has confirmed that all necessary documents have been filed and the cargo is cleared.

The inspection is scheduled for tomorrow morning at 9 AM.

I will forward the bill of lading copy shortly.

Regards,
Jake

From: andre.shipping@gmail.com
To: advisor@maritime-consulting.com
Subject: Container Ship Investment Query
Timestamp: 2024-01-15 09:30
Body: Hello Sir,

I'm considering an investment in the container shipping industry and would appreciate your thoughts. Do you think a large container ship will be built in China? Additionally, would it be better to own a small container ship outright or to have a partial interest in a large container vessel?

Thank you,
Andre

---
From: andre.shipping@gmail.com
To: advisor@maritime-consulting.com
Subject: Re: Container Ship Investment Query
Timestamp: 2024-01-17 14:15
Body: Dear Sir,

Since my last email, I've been studying a comprehensive book on the container shipping business and have developed some additional insights.

The shipping market is currently very strong, and I believe the container shipping industry will continue to grow. After analyzing the options, I'm leaning towards a specific conclusion: it appears more advantageous to own a small container ship outright rather than holding a partial interest in a large vessel.

I would appreciate your thoughts on this assessment.

Thank you,
Andre

---
From: andre.shipping@gmail.com
To: advisor@maritime-consulting.com
Subject: Re: Container Ship Investment Query
Timestamp: 2024-01-19 11:45
Body: Dear Sir,

After further research and careful consideration of the container shipping business, I've reached a firm conclusion. I am now convinced that owning a small container ship outright is the better strategy compared to having a partial interest in a large vessel. This approach offers more stability and control in the long term.

I look forward to your response regarding this decision.

Thank you,
Andre

A booking reference number is a unique number that is given to a customer when they make a booking for a product or service. The number is used to identify the customer's booking and to keep track of it. The number may be given to the customer in a confirmation email or letter, or it may be printed on the customer's booking form. The booking reference number is typically used to look up the customer's booking when they call or email to ask a question or make a change to their booking.

Email 1:
Dear Mr. Thomas,                    We’re looking to move   some dry bulk cargo from Apapa to Durban on short notice. Could you share your earliest loading window?                    Regards,                    Janelle
Email 2:
Dear Colleagues,      Our kind team is invited to London for IMO/SGS market hearing. Looking for your meeting schedule or collective guidance from DCS. What is your opinion for SGH support project?                            Regards,                    Ria

Answering both of these emails at the same time is often not possible. Even with the help of tools, like Changelog.io , can save time. 
Typically, you would need to spend some time each day, looking through the emails you’ve gotten, and only answer the ones you can actually answer, saving the others for later. 

A chat bot can also do that. With a Machine Learning and NLP model, the bot can answer the questions that it has answers to, or store them to answer later, and reply to your other colleagues later, with their questions still in place. 

If the first question above is related to
Email 3:
Dear Sir,
            We have procured the following machine tools & equipment for shipping to Japan / South Korea
                   <inquired item and price>
            could you let us know, what is the space that you can accommodate these machines?

Thank you for the kind offer. We need some more details to plan out for the work. Please fill out the following form: 
<...>
                Regards,
                Victor.

the bot would reply back with the appropriate answers, and then be able to answer similar questions in the future, as it trains its model.

input_text:
Email 1:
Mr. Silver,                    We’re looking for a 500 ton cargo of corn from Quebec to Tokyo. Could you provide a freight quote under CFR terms, and can your vessel sail before the 20th?                    Best regards,                    Gordon
Email 2:
Silver Shipping
Mr. Silver,
Thank you for your reply. We have already loaded on a vessel and made the transportation contract. However, the transportation company asks for the following documents: a set of bills of lading, a certificate of insurance and a set of commercial invoices. I would appreciate your advice.
Yours sincerely,
Tom

The problem of Cargo Document is tricky because it involves the dispute on whether the transportation company should be considered as the agent of the seller.

Business background:
The first email shows that the buyers have agreed on an acceptance to offer (letter of acceptance, cf. § 1384, Italian Code of Commercial law (Codice Commerciale)) and made a transportation contract for the 500 ton cargo of corn with a third party. As for the Seller, the second email shows that the Seller still thinks that the transportation company is his agent and the Buyers are not
Email 3:
Dear Gordon,
Silver Shipping, Inc. is currently arranging the shipping for you. It will be more convenient if you could tell us the name of the third party or the transportation company to deal with the shipping contract. We are looking forward to getting your email. Thank you very much.
Yours sincerely,
Michael Silver, President Silver Shipping, Inc.
</Email 3>

The main issue:
For the transaction to be a sale with CIF clause, at the moment of conclusion of the contract of sale, the Seller and the Buyers have to agree on the destination port and the Seller have to insure the goods for the Buyers. If the Buyers do not have a transportation contract, the Seller must comply with this CIF clause to fulfill the contract. Otherwise, the Seller should not promise the contract with the Buyers at all, which is the same as Article 6 § 1 (c) of the ICC
Email 4:
Gordon,
Mr. Silver would like to know where you have got the buyers of the corn. We have already got buyers but you asked for the freight and insurance costs. We do not understand why. As we agreed, you are responsible for the sale, insurance and transportation of the corn. We expect to see a written transportation contract from you within the next 3 days. Please forward to Mr. Silver a copy of the transportation contract.
Yours sincerely,
Bill
</Email 4>
The point is that the Seller has not decided what destination port the Buyers are going to choose yet. It seems that the Sellers have fulfilled all the CIF obligations in this case. Thus, it is unnecessary to involve any transportation company. If there is no such transportation company that the Seller and the Buyers both use, the contract of sale cannot be considered as a CIF contract. Therefore, the Sellers should not

input_text:
Email 1:
Hi Kathy,                    Has the grounding of the Seablue had any impact on your crude fixing level for the short term?                    Thanks,                    Blayney
Email 2:
Hi Blayney,                    Not at all.                    Seablue is a crude vessel and almost all crude cargoes have been fixed by the other time-chartered tankers coming out of  Chinese yards.
As I mentioned previously, if Seablue did not come out in China, other tankers would come out of the dock and China would be fixed.                    These tankers would operate at a price level set by the most competitive time charter tanker which is the drydocked Seablue and therefore the price level at which China is fixed would not be different even if Seablue was out of the drydock.
LPG cargoes are different since we can not use LPG in the crude tankers and crude cargoes are not as easy to fix as LPG, since many producers are contracted and certain prices are set.
The next drydocked Seablue is in
Email 3:
1. Sent 6:45PM
2. Sent 7:03PM

Teo

To: batra.vessels@outlook.com
Subject: Vessel Inquiry - Singapore to Colombo Motor Shipment
Timestamp: 2024-03-20 09:15
Body: Hello Mr. Batra,

We expect to ship 3,000MT of motors from Singapore to Colombo by April 1st. Would your vessel be available for a short term voyage, and are you flexible on ballast condition?

Best regards,
Ernest

---
From: batra.vessels@outlook.com
To: ernest.shipping@gmail.com
Subject: Re: Vessel Inquiry - Singapore to Colombo Motor Shipment
Timestamp: 2024-03-20 14:30
Body: Dear Mr. Ernest,

The 'Coastline' is currently berthed at Kakinada on Indian coast and I expect to receive her draft survey report around the 25th. Her charterers are currently assessing the bunkers required for Singapore, however, we may be able to depart for Singapore as early as 26th March.

Regarding ballast conditions, you could also consider 'Coastline's' current charterers (i.e. 'Sambalino' of the same owners) as they will be arriving from a short haul fixture and may be able to proceed immediately to the loading port in ballast. Alternatively, you may proceed ballast and obtain fuel in advance of loading.

Please let me know if you require any additional information.

Best regards,
Raj Batra

---
From: ernest.shipping@gmail.com
To: batra.vessels@outlook.com
Subject: Re: Vessel Inquiry - Singapore to Colombo Motor Shipment
Timestamp: 2024-03-21 10:45
Body: Hi Mr. Batra,

May I request you to explore the following options with your owners:

1. Send the 'Coastline' from Kakinada to your discharge port to arrive in 6 days time;
2. Send the 'Coastline' from Kakinada to your discharge port to arrive in 10 days time;
3. Send the 'Sambalino' from your discharge port to the Singapore loading port to arrive in 6 days time;
4. Send the 'Sambalino' from your discharge port to the Singapore loading port to arrive in 10 days time;

I will forward you the draft survey copy as soon as it's received. Please contact me if you need any further information.

Thanks,
Ernest

---

To: batra.vessels@outlook.com
Subject: Re: Vessel Inquiry - Singapore to Colombo Motor Shipment
Timestamp: 2024-03-23 16:20
Body: Dear Mr. Batra,

Best regards,
Ernest

input_text:
Email 1:
Hello Ms. Scott,                    Can you look at the market rate for 2 x 50foot containers of crude oil from Balikpapan to Jakarta, 22nd to 23rd of the month?                    Regards,                    Emma
Email 2:
Hi,                    We bought 2 x 50foot containers of crude oil from Balikpapan to Jakarta for 700 USD.                    All the best,                    Emma

After investigating 82 oil container rates in Balikpapan from February to May 2016, Emma wrote email 1 to request advice on market rates for the 22nd to 23rd of the month. When the suggested rate was below market rate, she accepted the offer via email 2.

Solution:
The correct answer is a2, and the explanation is as follows:
The business communication has the characteristic of taking the buyer's interest into consideration. The buyer is assumed to be the focus in business communication.
Email 3:
Dear Ms. Scott,                   We would like to purchase some crude oil. We have a request for a load of cargo delivered to China on or around the 22nd to 23rd of this month. What is the market rate for this?                    Regards,                    Emma

Answer Options:
a1. Email 3 asked the oil supplier for the market rate of oil containers and the price, which shows great concern for the buyer's interest.
a2. The oil supplier provides a quotation below the market rate in email 4, showing concern for the buyer's interest.
a3. The oil supplier provided a quotation that was on par with the market rate in email 4, showing no concern for the buyer's interest.
a4. The oil supplier provided a quotation that was much higher than the market rate in email 4, showing great concern for the buyer's interest.
a5

Cheers,
George

---
From: liam.brown@shipbroker.com
To: george.smith@trading.com
Subject: Re: Petcoke Cargo - Kandla to Mathura Inquiry
Timestamp: 2023-07-05 10:45
Body: Hi George,

Looks like some port delays going through Kandla. We only have tonnage fixed to Mumbai/Kochi. The next most recent port is Chennai. Do you have any interest in loading at Chennai?

Best Regards,
Liam

---
From: george.smith@trading.com
To: liam.brown@shipbroker.com
Subject: Re: Petcoke Cargo - Kandla to Mathura Inquiry
Timestamp: 2023-07-05 11:30
Body: Hi Liam,

Thanks for your reply. How about Mumbai for delivery? That would be okay with us.

Cheers,
George

---
From: liam.brown@shipbroker.com
To: george.smith@trading.com
Subject: Re: Petcoke Cargo - Kandla to Mathura Inquiry
Timestamp: 2023-07-05 13:15
Body: Hi George,

We only have one vessel in the Gulf that could arrive in Mumbai within your timeframes. It will be in Lasbela (Mub) on 11th July, and can be ready to load on the 13th or 14th July. It is available until 17th July. As it's currently chartered, the berth time will be 10 days at a minimum. The vessel is currently loading cargo in Tamil Nadu due to arrive in Mumbai on July 11th.

Best Regards,
Liam

---
From: liam.brown@shipbroker.com
To: george.smith@trading.com
Subject: Re: Petcoke Cargo - Kandla to Mathura Inquiry
Timestamp: 2023-07-05 15:45

Thank you for your interest. I have since received an enquiry for a different cargo type that the ship could load in Mumbai, so I'm going to offer it to the client in that case. Unfortunately, that means it's not available to you.

But please let me know if you are still interested in a ship that could load there, and I will be able to let you know whether the ship is free or not.

Best Regards,
Liam

    the quality and cleanliness of the cargo,
    the minimum temperature the cargo must be kept at on board,
    if you need a refrigerated vessel, and
    what type of stowage is required.

input_text:
Email 1:
Hi John,                    Our Singapore client would like to transport 2,800MT of naphtha from Baltimore to Dahej, but we don’t have enough funds on hand for the margin fee. Could you spot us?                    Hope you can help.                    Kim
Email 2:
From: John G                 Sent: 23 February 2012 18:00                 To: Kim T                 Subject: Spot us?                 Not a chance! Hope you can spot my answer.                 John

Problem

A recent widespread email spam campaign targeted the energy and commodities trading industry with messages claiming that their customers wanted to use their services to buy crude oil and related products from reputable traders in the market. Some traders were approached in a very business-like manner, allegedly by major oil firms. The email subject line would indicate that the email was from a trusted business partner, such as a large energy firm or similar corporate client.

The email requests are easy to read but hard to understand. A foreign sounding person claiming to be an executive from a respectable company in a similar industry wants to “spot” some “margin fee” – what? An explanation for what these terms mean may have come attached
Email 3:
Dear John,                    Thank you for your reply.                    Our Singapore client is Singapore Energy, one of the leading trading and logistics companies in Asia Pacific. They represent a major Japanese refiner, Osaka Gas.                    It’s true that this is a complicated trading project and we have to pay a relatively high margin fee of USD 1,000.000.                    If you don’t mind, I can arrange to send you the contract and payment procedure, so that you can fully understand the situation.                    Have a good day.                    Kim

When a business receives a large unsolicited order they often feel obligated to make the sale. In this instance, we can probably deduce that our client is confused as to what the client actually wants and also may be uncomfortable with all the business jargon. In both situations, the client should take a step back and evaluate the order. First, the client should
Email 4:
Dear John,                    Thank you for your reply.                    I am really sorry to trouble you. My name is Alihac, Assistant to the CEO of Singapore Energy.                    I’d like to discuss with you about the details of the project.                    Please let me know when you are free.                    Best regards,                    Kim

As the requests are unsolicited and we have not received any communication with our buyer in the past, it would be a good idea to contact them directly to confirm their intent. We could ask the buyer for more information and maybe arrange to speak with the buyer directly. When speaking with the buyer, it would be important to ask them to provide more information about the deal. The buyer may have a reasonable explanation for their request. However, it is important to keep in mind that a reasonable explanation does not necessarily mean the request is legitimate.

Conclusion

This type of email scam

Email 1:
Hi Reza,                    I’d like to schedule 40,000MT of molasses from Santos to Jawahar Nagar. We’re open to spot charterers, but this cargo may require some creativity in terms of planning. Could you please let me know if you are open to this size charter?                    Thank you,                    Rosalind
Email 2:
Hi Rosalind                    Just sent you a revised LSA with the same details.                    Best regards                    Reza

Thanks, Reza

Below is Rosalind's reaction to Reza's invitation.
Email 3:
You are good, its working perfect :)

All the best,
Rosalind

So she already appreciated the role of Reza’s proposing concrete example as shown in the second email above.

For general reference, a LSA is a LOI (letter of intent) document.

Introduction

The use of “Email 1” as an example is taken from a popular LinkedIn post of Sam Nara on the subject of using a working example when making a proposal (source: Linkedin).

I have learned a lot from Sam’s post, and I think the post helps provide an excellent practical starting point. In this post, I will provide further explanations to highlight more subtle points not included in Sam’s original post, and also discuss how these points are implemented in our Lean Email.

Email 1 is a typical email. Its objective is to propose a working example to a recipient.

In practice, Rosalind
Email 4:
Thank you so much!
<...>
I do need your help here to review and submit the revised LSA to admin for approvals!

In this example, Rosalind first thanked Reza for sending her a revised LSA, then reminded Reza that she required his help to proceed with the transaction.

Based on this email, Reza needs to do two things to support Rosalind in closing this transaction:

• Review the LSA before submitting the LSA to Rosalind’s admin for approvals.
• Submit the LSA to Rosalind’s admin for approvals.

Reza can do these two tasks simply by using Lean Email by clicking the buttons as shown below. Clicking on the Review button will pop-up a Review/Submit page, which contains a Review tab, and a Submit tab.

Clicking on the Review tab, Reza can simply enter a quick review note, and
output_text:

input_text:
Email 1:
Dear Ms. Armitage,                    Want to discuss options for a scheduled bulk chartered from Singapore to Jakarta, loading 15,000 MT of rice.                    Thanks,                    Sally
Email 2:
Ms. Armitage                    Hi Sally,                In reference to your email, we may consider to organize a chartered out of Singapore with loading to be completed by around 20 to 22 Nov, with delivery ETA expected to be around 10 to 12 Dec. For your reference, I have attached the chartered info and telex release copy.                If you are interested, I will keep you posted when we have further update.                Regards,                Tony

</Email 2>

# Word Problem

### Solution 1

From the email the relevant facts are:

• The farmer wants to charter a ship to transport 15000 mt of rice to Jakarta.
• According to Ms. Armitage, the loading can be completed by around 20–22 November with delivery ETA around 10–12 December.

We know the ship will depart Singapore to Jakarta but
Email 3:
Hi Sally,                There will be another chartered starting from Singapore to Jakarta, departing on 18 Nov.                If you are interested, please advise latest by 15 Nov.                Regards,                Tony

</Email 3>

The sender mentions in Email 3 that the ship will leave Singapore to Jakarta on 18 November. That means there will be a time difference between 18 November and 20 November. So this information is not consistent with the information given in Email 2, which is the main source of information.

One reason for inconsistency could be the mistake in Email 2, when Ms. Armitage wrote 22 November instead of 20 November. Or one may assume that when Ms. Armitage sent Email 2, she didn't know about the departure date on 18 November.

Let us consider the following situation:
Email 4:
Hi Sally,                There will be a chartered departing on 18 Nov, with delivery ETA expected to be around 10 to 12 Dec.                Please advise if you are interested by 15 Nov.                Regards,                Tony

</Email 4>

In Email 4, we assumed that Ms. Armitage may have made a mistake in Email 2, and corrected it in Email 4. So let us analyze this situation.

Assume the ship leaves Singapore on 18 November and arrives at Jakarta on 10 December. This means the ship will take 22 days to reach Jakarta.

So, if loading is completed on 20 November, it will take a minimum of 2 days to complete the loading. It may take longer.

• So the loading will take place between 18 and 20 November.
• Then, if the

From: robert.smith@tradingco.com
To: morris.sarah@portops.com
Subject: Rice Shipment to Matadi - Berth Congestion Query
Timestamp: 2024-02-15 09:23
Body: Hi Ms. Morris,

We have an enquiry for 13,000MT of rice from Colombo to Matadi. Can you give us a berth congestion forecast and how does your laytime allowance work in case of port delays?

Many thanks,
Robert

---
From: morris.sarah@portops.com
To: robert.smith@tradingco.com
Subject: Re: Rice Shipment to Matadi - Berth Congestion Query
Timestamp: 2024-02-15 11:45
Body: Dear Robert,

Matadi is currently experiencing high congestion levels. Please note the following:

- Typical waiting time for berth is 2-4 days
- No guaranteed transit time to discharge
- Berth queue is unpredictable as vessels can arrive without prior notice
- Terminal operates up to 2 berths simultaneously
- Berthing priority is assigned by the Terminal based on vessel readiness
- Reserved berth slots may be reassigned if vessel arrival is delayed due to congestion

I recommend factoring these conditions into your laytime calculations.

Best regards,
Sarah Morris

From: felipe.martinez@tradeco.com
To: perry.woo@freightservices.com
Subject: Freight Quote Request - Copenhagen to Lagos
Timestamp: 2024-02-01 09:15
Body: Dear Mr. Woo,

Could you please provide a 7-day freight estimate for 25,000MT of oil from Copenhagen to Lagos?

Thanks,
Felipe

---
From: perry.woo@freightservices.com
To: felipe.martinez@tradeco.com
Subject: Re: Freight Quote Request - Copenhagen to Lagos
Timestamp: 2024-02-01 10:30
Body: Dear Felipe,

25,000 tons of oil from Copenhagen to Lagos in a seven-day freight? That's quite a bit of oil. I assume you need to ship it by sea.

You see, the oil trade operates on a just-in-time inventory management model, whereby oil is shipped to tankers as needed. This provides a stable supply and demand, eliminates inventory storage costs and prevents oil from degrading over time.

Since your request involves shipping 25,000 tons of oil in seven days, my freight quote estimate would exceed what is available.

Please confirm that your request is for 25,000 tons of oil in a seven-day freight and I can provide a quote to the maximum that is available to my company.

Thanks,
Perry

---
From: felipe.martinez@tradeco.com
To: perry.woo@freightservices.com
Subject: Re: Freight Quote Request - Copenhagen to Lagos
Timestamp: 2024-02-01 11:45
Body: Dear Perry,

Yes, my request is for 25,000 tons for shipping in seven days to Lagos in Nigeria. Could you please provide a quote?

Thanks,
Felipe

---
From: perry.woo@freightservices.com
To: felipe.martinez@tradeco.com
Subject: Re: Freight Quote Request - Copenhagen to Lagos
Timestamp: 2024-02-01 14:20
Body: Dear Felipe,

Again, shipping 25,000 tons in seven days is an unusual request. If you are shipping this amount of oil in an outbound tanker, then the only companies capable of doing so are Shell, Chevron and Exxon. I don't have contacts with these companies.

If you're shipping by sea, then you'll need a port in Copenhagen to load onto a tanker. I've emailed my contacts in the seaport of Copenhagen. They'll be in touch with me in the morning.

If you're shipping by road, then the quantity would need to be in 45 liter plastic oil drums. The storage space and legal limitations of this option would be impossible to organize in such a short time frame.

I'm sorry, but I simply don't have the resources to fill your request. I recommend you submit your request to one of the three large oil companies I mentioned before.

Regards,
Perry

---
From: felipe.martinez@tradeco.com
To: perry.woo@freightservices.com
Subject: Re: Freight Quote Request - Copenhagen to Lagos
Timestamp: 2024-02-01 15:10
Body: Dear Perry,

I am absolutely okay with you contacting the seaport in Copenhagen. I understand that you don't have the resources to fulfill my request. I will be submitting my request to an oil company.

Thank you for your assistance,
Felipe

To: j.lewis@freightbrokers.com
Subject: Rate Request - Oil Seed Cake SPB/Seoul 7,500MT
Timestamp: 2023-03-15 09:30
Body: Hello Mr. Lewis,

Can you confirm rates for 7,500MT of oil seed cake from Saint Petersburg to Seoul? Please include details on length of laycan and any additional costs associated with accelerated discharge.

Regards,
Katherine

---
From: j.lewis@freightbrokers.com
To: katherine.smith@tradingco.com
Subject: Re: Rate Request - Oil Seed Cake SPB/Seoul 7,500MT
Timestamp: 2023-03-15 11:45
Body: Hi Katherine,

The following rates apply:

- Spot: $50 per mt over 20% IFM + 30/5/20 (laycan 7-10 days)
- Extended: $40 per mt over 20% IFM + 30/10/20 (laycan 10-14 days)
- Longer: $30 per mt over 20% IFM + 30/15/20 (laycan 14-21 days)

Fixed delay rate (FDR) applies as follows:
- $5 per day for the first 7 days
- $10 per day thereafter
(Example: if vessel delayed 8 days, FDR is $70 - ($5x7) + ($10x1))

Best regards,
James Lewis

---
From: j.lewis@freightbrokers.com
To: katherine.smith@tradingco.com
Subject: Re: Rate Request - Oil Seed Cake SPB/Seoul 7,500MT
Timestamp: 2023-03-15 12:15
Body: Hello Katherine,

Additional important information regarding your inquiry:

1. Accelerated discharge charges for +35 days cargo will be paid by Seller and are not included in the above rates.

2. Due to the busy season, vessel availability is limited during April-May 2023. We have several vessels that could be offered at these rates, but they are currently engaged in previous trades. We would require 20-30 days notice to arrange a ballast leg after their return to Russia.

I recommend booking soon if these terms work for you.

Best regards,
James Lewis

Hi Mr. Gonzales,                    We need to move 500kg of glass beads from Haparanda to Bergen, 2,500kg of microwave chocolate from Sodertalje to Umea, and 1,000kg of industrial scissors from Umea to Stockholm. Can you send a freight estimate for these shipments?                    Thanks,                    Henry
Email 2:
Hi Henry,                         I don't have an official price for these shipments. Please send me the addresses you have listed. I'll send the addresses to my colleagues in the different cities. They'll give me prices to ship your orders.                    Best regards,                    Hans
output_text:
From: customer@solarco.com
To: bookings@shippingline.com
Subject: Shipping Inquiry - Solar Panels Shanghai to Colombo
Timestamp: 2023-09-20 09:30
Body: Hello,

We are booking a shipment of solar panels for Colombo from Shanghai at the beginning of October. Could you please let me know if there will be any availability on your vessel at that time, and what the total costs for carriage from FOB Shanghai to Colombo would be?

Sincerely,
John Smith

---
From: bookings@shippingline.com
To: customer@solarco.com
Subject: Re: Shipping Inquiry - Solar Panels Shanghai to Colombo
Timestamp: 2023-09-20 14:15
Body: Dear Mr. Smith,

Thank you for your inquiry. We currently have no space available on our vessel for this shipment. Our other vessel is also fully booked until the end of September.

However, we will keep your information on file in case of any changes or cancellations with other shipments.

Sincerely,
Sarah Chen

---
From: bookings@shippingline.com
To: customer@solarco.com
Subject: Re: Shipping Inquiry - Solar Panels Shanghai to Colombo
Timestamp: 2023-09-22 10:00
Body: Dear Mr. Smith,

Our other vessel has now become available for this shipment. We have reserved space for you on the departure date of 2nd October.

The total costs for carriage from FOB Shanghai to Colombo are as follows:
+ Freight: $1000
+ Additional Costs: $250
Total: $1250

Please confirm whether you can accept these terms before we proceed with formal confirmation of booking.

Sincerely,
Sarah Chen

---
From: customer@solarco.com
To: bookings@shippingline.com
Subject: Re: Shipping Inquiry - Solar Panels Shanghai to Colombo
Timestamp: 2023-09-23 11:30
Body: Dear Ms. Chen,

I confirm that we accept these terms and conditions.

Best regards,
John Smith

---
From: bookings@shippingline.com
To: customer@solarco.com
Subject: Re: Shipping Inquiry - Solar Panels Shanghai to Colombo
Timestamp: 2023-09-23 15:45
Body: Dear Mr. Smith,

Thank you for confirming that you accept these terms. Our vessel will depart from Shanghai on the 2nd October and arrive at Colombo on the 18th October.

We look forward to working with you again in the future.

Sincerely,
Sarah Chen

---
From: bookings@shippingline.com
To: customer@solarco.com
Subject: Re: Shipping Inquiry - Solar Panels Shanghai to Colombo
Timestamp: 2023-10-01 09:00
Body: Dear Mr. Smith,

We would like to update you on the status of your shipment. Our vessel has arrived at Shanghai on schedule and is currently loading the cargo. We expect all loading to be complete by the end of this week.

We will keep you updated with any further developments.

Sincerely,
Sarah Chen

<Email 3>:
(Type email here…)

Notice how the email itself doesn't go into the input? That's where everything gets tricky. If you're using input with the type of email, then you should just do the following:

For starters, if you're using Angular 2, you'll want to import FormsModule.

Like so: import { FormsModule } from '@angular/forms';
Next, you'll need to add FormsModule to the imports array in the @NgModule declaration.

Like so: imports: [ BrowserModule, FormsModule ],

And you'll need to add [email] to the input tag.

This will give you an input that looks something like this:

At the end of the day, I found it quite trivial, and I suspect that most people would, too.

From: james.smith@trading.com
To: rudi.hansen@shipping.com
Subject: Caustic Soda Shipment - Limassol to Monrovia
Timestamp: 2011-07-11 09:23
Body: Mr. Rudi,

I'm wondering if you could assist with moving a few hundred MT of caustic soda from Limassol to Monrovia around the end of July. I'd really appreciate your help with this inquiry.

Thanks,
James

---
From: rudi.hansen@shipping.com
To: james.smith@trading.com
Subject: Re: Caustic Soda Shipment - Limassol to Monrovia
Timestamp: 2011-07-11 14:45
Body: Dear James,

The transit time is currently 28-30 days. Based on vessel capacity and port restrictions, we can accommodate 26 MT per week for a period of 6 weeks, totaling 156 MT over the full period.

Let me know if this arrangement would work for you.

Best regards,
Rudi

This is an opportunity to work for a leading company in Dubai, and I am confident you would be the right person to fill the role.                    As you would be involved in the day-to-day aspects of the office, you would have the opportunity to:                    • Manage admin & accounts for an offshore business                    • Prepare for internal and external audits                    • Communicate with clients via email and phone                    • Lias with HR, logistics and maintenance departments                    • Prepare performance reports                    • Resolve problems and queries in a timely manner                    Please let me know if you are interested. We look forward to hearing from you.                    With kind regards,                    Phillip.

Chris

Email 1:
Hi Jack,                    I’m trying to secure a spot for 20,000 MT of iron ore from Virginia to Turkey. After-hours berthing is an option, but we’re flexible. Could you get back to me with some options for the next week and next month?                    Thanks,                    Susanna
Email 2:
Just to follow up, we're still in need of options from Turkey. What do you suggest for a daily service to Turkey, starting next week? This is urgent.
    Dear Susanna,  
        Our liners operate out of Virginia, Houston and Long Beach, and to Istanbul, İzmir, Kütahya, and Antalya. We also have a weekly direct service to İzmir from Savannah. It’s a fast service, it takes about 14 days from loading in the US to discharging in Turkey. If you’re interested in shipping from Houston, it’s an 11 day trip to Antalya. All of these routes can be served from one of our 3 weekly services. For a monthly schedule, please visit our website. We don’t accept individual bookings, so you would need to find a freight forwarder or consolidator to place your booking.
    Jack

input_text:
Email 1:
I was interested in your article about refelective materials in Nature.                                         You had two equations for refractive index in the article.                                         I am trying to find a proof or derivation of one of those (the one that uses lambda and n) and wanted to see if you knew of a reference for it.                                         Thank you,                                         Daniel
Email 2:
Subject: f2=1-2n

Hi!

Thank you for your message. The equation n=1-sqrt(1-f)/2 is a very general one. It can be found in most books on electromagnetism and optics. I wrote down the reference where I first came across this equation in my Nature paper. Have a look at page 3. But you can also find it in more recent books on plasmonics. For example in a book by Jain.
Email 3:
Hello.

Do you have any notes or references for derivation of the equation, f2=1-2n, when n=4*Pi/lambda*d*n*d?

Thanks.

Daniel
Email 4:
Subject:  Re: f2=1-2n

Hi Daniel,

Your question is not directly related to this particular website, therefore I think I'll reply in an email.

The only literature I can think of are two references you probably already have found yourself:

(1)  P. Drude, Handbuch der Radiologie, Leipzig: Barth, 1922 (p. 369)

(2)  N. Jain, C. J. Kryzhanovsky, and C. H. Chen, Excitation and Detection of Surface Plasmons on Gold Films. In: T. Zimmermann, and A. Berger, eds., Coherence, Statistics, and Quantum Optics IV (Springer, 2005) 146-165

Drude's book is basically the bible on metallic materials in
Email 5:
Subject:  Re: f2=1-2n

Hi Wim.

Thanks for your reply. I found that references and have already read them but I was looking for a clearer derivation that shows how the refractive index in that form, d*n/d, gets related to the frequency, lambda, and amplitude of the refractive index.

Thanks.

Daniel
<Email 6>:
Subject:  Re: f2=1-2n

Hi Daniel,

I am not sure that there is a clear derivation that you are looking for. You can find it in some other books, but I doubt that you will be very happy with it, since the derivation would be so clear.

I would be very happy if someone from the audience of this website can help you by giving a clear derivation of f2=1-2n.
<Email 7>:
Subject

It’s a big problem.

<Email 4>:
Good afternoon. Glad to hear from you. Hope you are doing fine. Thank you so much for the great video. There is no doubt it is very helpful for us. 
One question I have is when I sent a message by email, can I use "This is" to introduce myself? I saw a very interesting movie at the cinema. It is about a cat with a magic ability. What do you think about it? The movie is really enjoyable.
Thanks a lot.
Kevin
_______________________________________________________________________
Good
Email 4:
Good afternoon. Glad to hear from you. Hope you are doing fine. Thank you so much for the great video. There is no doubt it is very helpful for us. 
One question I have is when I sent a message by email, can I use "This is" to introduce myself? I saw a very interesting movie at the cinema. It is about a cat with a magic ability. What do you think about it? The movie is really enjoyable.
Thanks a lot.
Kevin
_______________________________________________________________________
Good

<Email 4>:
 Hello Kevin, Thank you so much for sending us a lovely song. Your friend Kevin is a great singer. Your English is really good, too. I'm happy you wrote to us. You can use "This is" to introduce your message. You can say something like "This is a song my friend Kevin sings." "This is an email I sent my friend Kelly last week." You can ask a question and talk about a movie like this: "How was the movie about the cat with a magic ability? It sounds interesting." Or you can say, "I'm glad you liked the movie about the cat with a magic ability." I hope you have a great day. Be well! Olivia and the Yip sisters.

Dear Ms. Flippo,

I was copied on your email yesterday to Mr. Frank and Messrs. Calloway and Vaughn. Please be advised that pursuant to Section 14.4 of the Purchase Agreement dated November 4, 2004, we have placed certain assets that are subject to the asset transfer agreement that you recently sent over to us in our depository at 15 York St., in Toronto, to await the return of those assets to ABC. These assets are detailed in a list attached to our email of December 14, 2004, (see attachment A). I assume these are the assets that are under your custody. If you have any objections to this deposit, you must advise us
Email 4:
[RECEIVED AT TIME OF EMAIL]
Dear Mr. McGroarty,
Thank you for your email. Please be advised that we have no objections to the list you provided to us. However, the list in question has not been previously reviewed by the Board of Directors of ABC and therefore we are unable to provide you with any information regarding the specific assets. It is our understanding that our list does not conform to the requirements of the Sale Agreement, particularly since the list reflects that we are permitted to retain certain files and information despite the fact that we are prohibited from using or retaining any ABC Confidential Information, as set out in the Sale Agreement. This is a concern to our Board of Directors.

Please be advised that your proposal to place certain of our assets in a depository pending return to ABC is inappropriate and contrary to the terms of the Sale Agreement. Specifically, Section 2.1(a)
Email 5:
I just spoke with Martin but I was copied on the email below. 
    Today is December 17th, 2004 and we continue to have no approved and executed sale agreement. In the meantime, ABC is purging all of our assets and information, and sending same to various unidentified third parties and law firms. 
     We simply cannot accept these proposals in light of ABC's wrongful purging of our assets. All of the discussion contained in your email is irrelevant in light of the purging. Please provide us with a confirmed list of all assets that have been sent to third parties and their names. 
<Email 6>:
Dear Mr. McGroarty,

<Body>: You must withdraw any claim that ABC has breached the purchase agreement. You are not our trading partner; you are our custodian, holding assets that belong to ABC until such time as the transaction is closed

From: vitoria.santos@shipbroker.com
To: carlos.martinez@tankers.com
Subject: Kerosene Shipment NOLA-JAX
Timestamp: 2005-04-05 14:30
Body: Hi Carlos,

Could you take on 11,400MT of kerosene from New Orleans to Jacksonville? Any ideas on extra insurance premiums for weekend deliveries?

Thanks,
Vitoria

---
From: bob.smith@maritime.com
To: dave.wilson@tankers.com
Subject: Re: Kerosene Shipment NOLA-JAX
Timestamp: 2005-04-05 15:15
Body: Dave,

I checked the surface tanker jet fuel route chart. The distance is only 275 miles, potentially 250 if cutting through the shallows. With the shallowest part at 43 feet, a 35,000 ton tanker would only need about 16' of water draft.

While vessel passage shouldn't be an issue, insurance premiums might be higher due to limited refueling options along the route. However, I'm not seeing any suitable tankers available at the moment.

Regards,
Bob

---
From: bob.loeschcke@maritime.com
To: al.williams@shipping.com
Subject: Surface Tanker Route Documentation
Timestamp: 2005-04-05 16:20
Body: Al,

I have uploaded the PDF file to 'www.surfacetankers.info'. Please confirm if you can access it.

Thanks!
Bob Loeschcke

---
From: al.williams@shipping.com
To: group@maritime.com
Subject: RE: IN/OUT service of 250K+ Tankers between Miami and Rio de Janeiro
Timestamp: 2005-04-05 18:43
Body: Found the Ghyben-Herzberg limited water zone map on surfacetankers.info - exactly what we needed!

By the way, if anyone knows of a 250K bbl tanker (approx. 12M gallons) available for Brazil route, please connect us. Looking to arrange offloading in the Bahamas.

input_text:
Email 1:
Hello,                    We are shipping 200CTNs of T-shirts from Shanghai to Paris. Do you have space this month and how soon can we get a price?                    Regards,                    Jean
Email 2:
Hi Jean,
Thank you for your email. I would like to ask you some information regarding your shipment of t-shirts:
1) What is the mark or brand of the t-shirts?
2) What type of t-shirt is it? Tank, tube, long sleeve, short sleeve?
3) Is the t-shirt knitted or woven?  And what kind of knit or weave?
4) Does it have any decoration on it? What type of decoration?
5) What type of fabric is it?  What is the denier, threads, and fiber count?
6) What is the weight of a t-shirt?
7) Do you want us to pay for the cost of freight, or do you want us to put it on your invoice?
8) How many items in one package?
If you have any questions, please feel free to ask.
Best regards,
Yue

From: mabena.trading@company.com
To: yasmina.shipping@company.com
Subject: Base Oil Shipment to Yemen - Documentation Query
Timestamp: 2024-01-15 09:30
Body: Hi Yasmina,

We have 7.4kMT of base oil ready in Malta and looking to arrange shipment to Yemen. How long would it take to prepare the necessary documents and can you accept delivery within 48 hours?

Yours sincerely,
Mabena

---
From: yasmina.shipping@company.com
To: mabena.trading@company.com
Subject: Re: Base Oil Shipment to Yemen - Documentation Query
Timestamp: 2024-01-15 11:45
Body: Hi Mabena,

Thank you for your email.

Unfortunately, the Yemen Embassy in Malta does not accept direct applications. For the required documentation, you must process this through your employing company or a sponsoring company.

Yours sincerely,
Yasmina

---
From: mabena.trading@company.com
To: yasmina.shipping@company.com
Subject: Re: Base Oil Shipment to Yemen - Documentation Query
Timestamp: 2024-01-15 14:20
Body: Hi Yasmina,

Thanks for the information. There are only two company representatives in Malta and they're both unavailable. What if I'm not employed directly by the company? Can a sponsor company assist with the Yemen documentation? Do you know any sponsor companies I could contact?

Yours sincerely,
Mabena

---
From: mabena.trading@company.com
To: yasmina.shipping@company.com
Subject: Re: Base Oil Shipment to Yemen - Documentation Query
Timestamp: 2024-01-16 08:15
Body: Thanks for the info, I'll visit both the company office and embassy today to make some enquiries.

Regards,
Mabena

---
From: mabena.trading@company.com
To: yasmina.shipping@company.com
Subject: Re: Base Oil Shipment to Yemen - Documentation Query
Timestamp: 2024-01-17 09:00
Body: Hi Yasmina,

I visited the embassy in Malta yesterday. The staff were very helpful and informed me that no sponsor is actually needed. The visa cost is 118 USD.

Hope this information helps you.

Yours sincerely,
Mabena

Email 1:
Dear Mr. Walters,                    We have cargo for 12,000MT of urea from Pengerang to Las Palmas in September.                   BAF should be around $120/mt (based on old fix as BAF has changed dramatically), however if a GdW is used please be aware the vessel will likely be late when BAF is calculated. 
About this post:                   It’s useful to think about what someone needs to know (what information they need) and how you can present it to them (the style you can use).                    This helps you to produce emails that are both concise and comprehensive.                    It helps you to be consistent in your writing, and the person receiving your email will feel reassured by the consistency of style (if you can remember to use it!)                    And, if you use the same style for several emails to the same person, it
Email 2:
Dear Mrs. Walters, 
               We are still in contact with our vendors in Nanded and are anticipating a price at the end of next week for up to 20,000MT of various types of urea. As the quantities can change daily, we would like you to provide the last two digits of your credit card number. 
               I will call you later today to discuss this and to arrange for a flight to Mumbai. As you know, we need to be flexible on the types of urea and quantities, but please feel free to send a list of your requirements. We are anticipating that we may receive it in three or four shipments, so that may be something to consider. Please also provide us with a list of the vessels that you have available. 
               We are looking forward to seeing you. 
               Hope this helps, thanks, Jane

Email 1:
Hi,                    We need 1,200MT of lumber from Miami to Aruba. Can you please get us a price?                    Many thanks,                    Manuel
Email 2:
Dear <MANUEL>,
I have good news and bad news. The good news is that I have the freight prices
for Miami to Aruba, and the bad news is that the prices are sky high.
I'll be happy to help with the planning of the move, but I'm afraid that there is
no way that you can make that transport by boat. Unless you want to take a
steamer to South America and leave your lumber there, I would suggest that you
wait until the next hurricane season, when you'll find the rate a little bit lower.
Good luck with the move.
Best wishes,
Paul

input_text:
Email 1:
Dear Mrs. Michelotti,                    I’m inquiring about a shipment of 10,000MT of latex for export to Valencia. Your 2013 vessel performance seems strong, and I’d like to see if we can get your ship again.                    Sincerely,                    Gianfranco
Email 2:
Dear Mr. Gianfranco,                    The staff has been working hard to find out if we can get you the vessel for the required time. We can have the ship at Valencia on August 12, but this will force us to delay your departure time to August 18. Let us know if this is acceptable, and then we can close the deal.                    Warmly,                    Nicoletta

Since then, Nicolas has been waiting for an answer. When should he send a follow-up email?

## What the Social Norms Suggest

I asked 100 people the following question: Is it acceptable to wait for more than 10 days after an email is sent and not hear back? 35% of people said yes, 65% said no. So, what should he do?

## What the Stats Show

The text analysis service I use, Linguamatics, returned
Email 3:
At a first glance the email looks like the perfect email to send for this scenario; however, this is not the case as it is not very friendly. This could lead to someone feeling undermined, which could lead to the email recipient ignoring this email in hopes of less negativity from the sender. Which is the opposite of what we want. If we were to send this email to a sales person in hopes of securing the sale we would be sabotaging our chances of getting the sale because the person we are sending this to, may feel undermined and will respond less happily than if we had sent the second email. As well as providing a better response, the second email provides all of the information needed to complete the transaction and then asks for the decision. This shows professionalism and a desire to complete the transaction on both ends. In both cases the email offers the promise of a future reply, this may be the
Email 4:
I have been wondering when I will hear back about the shipment of latex for Valencia. August 12 is the deadline, so we need to make a decision soon. Please let me know if the August 18 date for departure is acceptable, and then we can close the deal.                    Warmly,                    Nicolas
@source_envisage: How long would you wait to get a response to an email?

Email 1:
Dear Ms. Patel,                    I need to send 1,000MT of maize from Poti to Zelenodolsk before the end of this week. What is your earliest loading date? And what kind of dispatch incentives do you offer?                    Best regards,                    Rudolf
Email 2:
Dear Mr. Tofts,                I can offer you the cheapest shipping options from Poti to Zelenodolsk: the transit time is only 5 days. Please check our webpage: https://baltshipping.net/en/shipping-port-poti/                    I will be very glad to see you soon in Poti!                    Best regards,                    Rudolf

The first email describes a negotiation for the sale of a commodity (in this case, maize). This kind of email, which we refer to as a negotiation email, is an important genre for a business that engages in negotiation with potential buyers and sellers. 

You can use such a negotiation email as an inspiration for your own, when you negotiate with a partner company. In the following paragraphs, I will discuss the parts of the above example email, showing you how they were composed, why they are important, and what the pros and
Email 3:
Dear Ms. Bellichi,                Please take a look at our offers and choose a suitable one. The earlier you confirm, the better discount we can offer. Thanks for your attention.                    Best regards,                    Antanina

This is the reply to an inquiry email, i.e. an email that responds to a potential customer's inquiry about the products and services offered by a company. It contains all the information the recipient needs and provides enough context for her to make a decision, including the pricing and the delivery terms.
Email 4:
Dear Ms. Samsya,                     We will send you a quote shortly. Have a nice day.                    Best regards,                    Ido

Hello!
Thank you for your request!
Your quote will be with you very soon.
Have a nice day.
Yours,
The Fones team

This is the end of the email, which is as important as its beginning. If the body of an email ends with a formality, it feels nice and appropriate to the recipient. However, if the ending part of the email contains information that does not pertain to the topic of the email, it may be confusing.
Email 5:
Hello!
Thank you for your request!
Your quote will be with you very soon.
Have a nice day.
Yours,
The Fones team

From: jim.peterson@orthocomfort.com
To: tech.support@shoeindustry.org
Subject: Technical Assistance Request - Shoe Durability Issues
Timestamp: 2024-01-15 09:23
Body: Dear Technical Support Team,

I'm looking for some help, and I was hoping you could point me in the right direction.

I work for OrthoComfort Manufacturing, and we've been getting a lot of complaints about our orthopedic shoes falling apart. It seems to happen whenever a patient uses our shoes to do a heavy activity, like basketball or soccer.

Our shoes are made with the same materials as the other brands that are out there, so I don't understand why our shoes would be falling apart faster. I'm wondering if there's something wrong with our manufacturing process, or if there's some other reason that our shoes would be breaking more easily.

Can you help me out?

Many thanks,
Jim Peterson
Quality Control Manager
OrthoComfort Manufacturing

Body: Dear Enzo,

Week 2: Load cargo in Cuxhaven, voyage to Halifax, load more cargo in Halifax, voyage to Boston, offload cargo in Boston

Stella

---
From: stella.parker@seachartering.com
To: enzo.martini@globalshipping.com
Subject: Re: Vessel Charter Request - Survey Results
Timestamp: 2024-01-22 16:45
Body: Dear Enzo,

As promised, I have prepared a comprehensive analysis of the ORIFLAMM survey data, along with a list of repairs, ratings, and observations. You may review this document and advise us whether we should proceed to purchase the vessel or not.

There are a few issues with the vessel that are a cause for concern, however it should be possible to address these issues without significantly compromising vessel integrity.

The main concerns are a cracked main engine bearing housing and the state of some of the steering equipment. I recommend having these issues looked at by a professional marine surveyor.

Sincerely,
Stella

Dear Tito,                    Thanks for your e-mail. Actually you should pay attention to the page number on each e-mail, the 89,000 is from my email 3, and the 90,000 is from my email 1. So you can choose 89,000 or 90,000. You can do CIF terms.                    Validitiy is 60 days.                    Regards,                    Wang

input_text:
Email 1:
Hello Owen,                    Our Australian customer wants to ship some powdered milk from Port Botany in Sydney to Tokyo. The contract says 2,500MT, but they might also require 1,500MT of grain. This order will leave in the first week of July. We need your help.                    How much would shipping 4,000MT of both goods together cost, and do you see any risk of port congestion?                    Many thanks,                    Ivy
Email 2:
Hi Ivy,
Good morning.

The order for 2,500MT should be easy to manage.
Regarding the order for 1,500MT of grain, unfortunately, we do not see any vessel available to fit both cargoes in the same vessel. As we are still in June, there are still some free slots available on July, but as the order size is so big, we have limited choices.
That being said, we can manage to fit 1,000MT of milk powder and 1,500MT of grain in the same vessel with the owner of a 10,000dwt M/V which is due to discharge the previous cargo in July. All details about the vessel are as follows:

M/V T1
Type    General Cargo
Flag    Liberia
Call    MOYO
Deadweight    8,600MT
Built    1996
Hold No
Email 3:
Regarding the risk of port congestion in Australia, I'm afraid the situation is getting worse and that it may be difficult to find a slot for such a big order. Also, the railway terminals are overloaded as well.
I know the situation seems very bad. I can only offer you the best available. If you are willing to wait till October, I can offer you a better slot with more space. This way, you will be able to fit more products, or reduce the price.
What do you think?
Email 4:
Thank you for your help. The information you provided is very useful to us. 
We want to ship the 4,000MT cargo in early July. We do not have enough storage capacity, so if we delay the delivery, it may lead to the depreciation of our goods, so I'm afraid we can only choose the original plan.
Also, we will have more orders to deliver in July. Can you please help us?
Waiting for your reply!
Regards,
Ivy
Best regards,
Martin
Email 5:
Hi Ivy,

I understand that you have to deliver the order at the earliest opportunity, and that you can't wait till October. I'll look for a slot in September for you.

Please find attached a quotation for 3,000MT and 4,000MT. We can ship 1,000MT in July and 2,000MT or 3,000MT in August. I can fit 2,000MT on a 6,000dwt M/V which is due to discharge in September and 3,000MT on a 6,500dwt M/V which is due to discharge in September as well.

Do you have a choice of milk powder or grain as the cargo to be shipped in August?
Thank you.

Regards,
Martin

Email 1:
Hello Ben,                    We’re looking to ship 20,000MT of steel from Paldock to Monrovia. Could you send us your fcl rate and ETA? Also, is it possible to do a post-dated bill of lading?                    Thanks,                    Grace
Email 2:
Hi Grace,                    Attached you will find our quotations for Paldock to Monrovia for your steel cargo.                    We will send your cargo within three days of receipt of your irrevocable letter of credit in our account in London.                    Could you confirm that the steel can be shipped in containers? If not, do you have other requirements (such as barge?); and do you have any requirements for the steel?                    We can carry the bill of lading either to bearer or to the order of your bank, as you require.                    If you would like us to carry the bill of lading to bearer, please let us know when to expect the irrevocable letter of credit in our London account.                    You will find our payment terms at the bottom of the quotations.                    Please confirm your requirements and send us a draft irrevocable letter of credit to enable
Email 3:
Thank you very much.                    The cargo will be shipped in 20 foot containers, with 400 pieces per container. The cargo will be steel bars.                    Please deliver the bill of lading to bearer.                    I have forwarded the irrevocable letter of credit.                    Best regards,                    Grace
Email 4:
Hello,                    We have received your request.                    We will charge you USD 700 per 20 foot container.                    We will deliver the bill of lading as follows:                    We will issue the bill of lading to bearer.                    We will send the bill of lading and the other shipping documents to you within five days of the date that we receive the irrevocable letter of credit in our account in London.                    Best regards,                    Ben
You will see that in the first two emails, Ben goes a little off track. In the first email he doesn’t send the fcl rate and ETA. In the second email, he starts to talk about letters of credit when Grace never asked about that.

Back to the example in Ben’s favour

input_text:
Email 1:
<BEGIN EMAIL C>                    Ms. Stevens:                    I will be at your office tomorrow for 30 minutes. Please let me know if you're free or if you want to meet elsewhere.                    Sincerely,                    Nastya
Email 2:
<BEGIN EMAIL C>                    I'm totally free tomorrow. See you tomorrow!                    Sincerely,                    Nastya

One of my workmates asked me how to answer this email. I am not sure myself. I've answered questions like these one here, but they were much more easy:

1)  Say good night to Mommy!
2)  Well, take your time!
3)  Of course I'll help you. When and where?
4)  That sounds great! I'll bring the umbrella.
5)  I know. It is not important.

What is the correct way to answer to Nastya in this email?

There is a pattern for this type of 2-part email that I've observed in some specific contexts:

1. The first part is like a sign-off: "Sincerely, Nastya". 2. The second part is the
Email 3:
<My name here> looks forward to your response.
<Email 4>:
<My name here> looks forward to speaking with you further.
<Email 5>:
<My name here> looks forward to meeting with you.
<Email 6>:
<My name here> looks forward to your call.
<Email 7>:
<My name here> looks forward to learning more about your situation.


This usage appears to be common in the auto industry, with online car reviews.

Here is a blog post on this, which cites a data-driven analysis from a company called Radian6:

https://hbr.org/2013/01/the-secret-language-of-email

If we take that at face value, then one possible answer to the email in the question is:

[EMAIL 8]
Please let me know if you're free or if you want to meet elsewhere.
[EMAIL 9]
Email 4:
<My name here> looks forward to speaking with you further.
<Email 5>:
<My name here> looks forward to meeting with you.
<Email 6>:
<My name here> looks forward to your call.
<Email 7>:
<My name here> looks forward to learning more about your situation.

[EMAIL 9]

<Email 4>:
 We look forward to learning more about your situation.

Timestamp: 2023-07-10 09:15
Body: Good day Ms. Kelly,

I'm inquiring about the possibility of shipping 3,400MT of sulphuric acid from Aqaba to Khor Fakkan. Could you handle a late-July laycan, and are you open to a short load window?

Best regards,
J. Pye

---
From: m.kelly@freightservices.com
To: j.pye@aqabatrading.com
Subject: Re: Sulphuric Acid Shipment Inquiry - Aqaba to Khor Fakkan
Timestamp: 2023-07-10 14:22
Body: Dear J. Pye,

Thank you for your inquiry. We can accommodate a late July load date, however please note that securing the necessary permits for hazardous cargo may take several weeks. A load window of 3-4 days is possible, but this will need to be specified in the permits.

We recommend engaging a local agent to expedite the permit process. Given the nature of the cargo, all documentation must be handled with appropriate care and attention.

Best regards,
M. Kelly

Best regards,
James

---
From: j.michaels@shippingbroker.com
To: yumyum.ashley@ryemiley.com
Subject: Re: Rye Miley (a garbage company) email
Timestamp: 2020-05-18 09:15
Body: Ashley,

- What type of waste material is being transported?
- Are there any hazardous materials involved?
- Can you confirm the final destination and intended disposal method?

Please note that we must ensure compliance with all relevant regulations.

Regards,
James

---

Ashley

---

To: yumyum.ashley@ryemiley.com
Subject: Re: Rye Miley (a garbage company) email
Timestamp: 2020-05-18 11:45
Body: Ashley,

James

input_text:
Email 1:
Hello X,                    We want to charter a vessel to transport 2k MT of petroleum coke from Baku to Qingdao, China. Do you have any ship open in November?                    Regards,                    [name]
Email 2:
Hello,                    Best Price on spot by sea transport:                0,19 $/MT + 0,05$/MT bunker.                Subject: bunker..................  1/5 charter party done on GLS 2/5 cargo -petroleum coke - 20k MT 3/5 B/L paid - 100 % 4/5 sailing November 5/5 From - Baku, Azerbaijan to - Qingdao, China                Best Regards, [name]

What is the task?                    The task is to find an empty container, go to China (pay 0.19$/MT + 0.05$/MT bunker) and bring petroleum coke to Azerbaijan (20k MT, 100% B/L paid, sailing in November).

The main question for this task is, does the company have a vessel available to take the cargo?

What technique(s)
Email 3:
The main trick is to make this task look like it is for open charter. This makes the victim pay attention to the price, believing it is actually lower than the price of the chartered ship (by the way, let's make it 0.19$). By saying that you will pay 0.05$/MT for bunker, the victim thinks you are buying bunker, while you are actually renting the vessel.

    Also note that the shipping cost (0.19$) is given to the nearest part of the fourth decimal place, which might look suspicious if the sender and receiver have different countries. It is a very good trick to make such mistakes, as I did in email 2, or even in email 1 if the victim is inexperienced. It makes the victim think he is comparing two similar offers, which they are not, and look bad for not noticing it. Finally

To: habib.rahman@qasimport.com
Subject: Re: HFO Cargo Inquiry - Panama to Port Qasim
Timestamp: 2024-02-15 14:30
Body: Dear Mr. Habib,

The vessel Sun Dragon that we have arranged the charter for to deliver the parcel of oil that you requested has taken on the cargo at the Panama Canal. It is currently waiting for a berth at Port Qasim. Unfortunately, its ship-to-ship transfer hoses were damaged in a recent collision and the ship's owner does not wish to risk using a new or used set of hoses that might fail again. Instead they have ordered a new set of hoses which will take a couple of weeks to deliver and install.

Please let me know if there is any alternative means that we can use to load the cargo and I'll try to make the necessary arrangements to comply with your request.

Regards,
Simon

Good morning Robert,                    Just checking in to see how everything is going. Our vessel just arrived in port yesterday and has been off-hire since 2pm. We also hear that other vessels are being loaded in a first-come, first-served basis which may cause a delay in our ETA.                    Please advise and let me know if you have any questions.                    Best,                    Stefan
Email 2:
I know that our vessel is at berth 1 and our ETA is on Friday and that is what I have been communicating to you, that is why I’m asking you if you have other updates. Robert, if you have any further updates please contact me as soon as possible.

Hello Robert, I tried to reach you earlier today and was unable to connect. If we could have a phone call later today that would be ideal.
Email 3:
We will be going through security tonight at 22:00. I have the ETA as 06:30 on Thursday. We have been told that there will be a job and a blast if necessary. Please be sure to let us know so we can follow up with them. If you have any further information, please let us know.

Thanks,
Michael

From: luis.martinez@shipper.com
To: riccardo.vessel@carrier.com
Subject: Salt Cargo Loading Request - Puerto Montt
Timestamp: 2023-07-25 09:30
Body: Let me know when your vessel is going to leave San Lorenzo with their cargo. I have 1500 MT of salt we would like to load in Puerto Montt. Could you send me the port information and also please confirm the tonnage and capacity of your vessel.

Best regards,
Luis

---
From: riccardo.vessel@carrier.com
To: luis.martinez@shipper.com
Subject: Re: Salt Cargo Loading Request - Puerto Montt
Timestamp: 2023-07-25 14:45
Body: Thank you for your email. We will arrive on Tuesday July 28 and stay overnight. We will load on Wednesday, the 29th at 09:00 local time. I attach herewith a copy of the port information for your files.

Sincerely,
Riccardo

---
From: armando.logistics@terminal.com
To: riccardo.vessel@carrier.com
Subject: Re: Oversized Equipment Loading - Punta Arenas
Timestamp: 2023-07-26 10:15
Body: Dear Mr. Riccardo,

Please confirm that your vessel will stay at anchorage at least for 2 days after arrival, we have to move an oversized equipment to the vessel at the Port of Punta Arenas.

Best regards,
Armando

---

To: multiple@recipients.com
Subject: Re: Port Call Schedule Update
Timestamp: 2023-07-26 15:30
Body: Hello Guys,

The port of call in Timbuktu will be on February 4th and we will stay over there for one day. Please be sure to have the correct shipment documentation available on board.

Best regards,
Helmut

input_text:
Email 1:
Dear Sir/Madam,                    We’d like to transport 2,900MT of cotton to Ghent from Huangpu. Could you let us know your best available rate, and do you work on a FCA basis?                    Thank you for your time,                    Henry
Email 2:
Dear Henry,                        Thanks for your mail. And I will try my best to find out the info from our cargo department. Best regards,                        Clark Chen
Email 3:
Dear Clark Chen,                     I am glad to hear from you. You could try any carrier please. If they have empty sailings, they would be happy to carry our goods, for our cargo is different from other goods, we transport it through containers instead of using trucks, so our goods are more sensitive.                     Let me know if you have questions or suggestions.                     Thank you!                     Henry
<Email 4>:
Dear Clark Chen,                     Thanks for your reply. Could you tell me which is the best choice? Our cargo usually transports at least 100,000 tons at a time. Is it better to transport by the whole container or shipper’s owned container?                     Please let me know if you have questions or suggestions.                     Thanks for your time!                     Henry
<Email 5>:
Dear Henry,                        Thanks for your mail. Sorry for my delay.                        By

From: john.smith@tradingco.com
To: frank.wilson@sugarexport.com
Subject: Sugar Shipment Quotation - LA to Seattle
Timestamp: 2024-01-15 09:30
Body: Dear Frank,

I am writing to provide initial terms for the sugar shipment. The price of granulated sugar in Los Angeles is $2,600/MT. Our credit terms are 30% deposit plus 70% on sight payment against the bill of lading. My colleague, George, is ready to conclude a formal contract and schedule the vessel.

Looking forward to hearing from you.

Best regards,
John

---
From: frank.wilson@sugarexport.com
To: kelsey.brown@importco.com
Subject: Re: Sugar Shipment Quotation - LA to Seattle
Timestamp: 2024-01-15 11:45
Body: Dear Kelsey,

Please find attached a quotation for the delivery of 4,500 MT of granulated sugar from Los Angeles to Seattle. To pay 30% of the value in advance and the balance against the B/L, you are required to make a bank to bank transfer within three working days of the date of this offer.

Should you require any further details, please do not hesitate to contact me.

Best regards,
Frank

---
From: kelsey.brown@importco.com
To: frank.wilson@sugarexport.com
Subject: Re: Sugar Shipment Quotation - LA to Seattle
Timestamp: 2024-01-15 14:20
Body: Hi Frank,

Thanks for letting me know. Could you explain the insurance to me in more detail? Is there a chance that we can pay 30% and the other 70% on the loading of the vessel?

Best regards,
Kelsey

---
From: kelsey.brown@importco.com
To: frank.wilson@sugarexport.com
Subject: Re: Sugar Shipment Quotation - LA to Seattle
Timestamp: 2024-01-16 10:15
Body: Frank,

Thank you for your message. As the details have already been discussed over email, we will now go ahead with the bank to bank transfer. Looking forward to doing business with you.

Regards,
Kelsey

Timestamp: 2024-02-01 09:15
Body: Hello Ms. Ferrara,

We're exploring rates for 4,500MT of adhesives from Hamburg to Aarhus. Would it be possible to combine cargo with any existing fixture, and what's your demurrage rate?

Thanks,
Ivy

---
From: ivy.chen@cargotrading.com
To: maria.ferrara@shipbroker.com
Subject: Re: Rate Inquiry - 4,500MT Adhesives Hamburg/Aarhus
Timestamp: 2024-02-02 14:30
Body: Hi Ms. Ferrara,

Following up about my email above. Is there any way you might be able to offer a lower rate? We have multiple shipments of this cargo, and it would be helpful to negotiate rates with you once.

Thank you!
Ivy

---
From: ivy.chen@cargotrading.com
To: maria.ferrara@shipbroker.com
Subject: Re: Rate Inquiry - 4,500MT Adhesives Hamburg/Aarhus
Timestamp: 2024-02-03 10:45
Body: Hi Ms. Ferrara,

I wanted to clarify my previous message. I understand that for the current fixture, a lower rate isn't possible. I'm mainly inquiring about whether future fixtures might have space for our product.

Thanks,
Ivy

---

To: ivy.chen@cargotrading.com

Body: Hi Ivy,

Best regards,
Maria

Could you inform us whether you are using XYZ Insurance Company? We are informed that they are a reputable company but that they are paying out large claims in many cases.                    Thanks,                    Tracy

input_text:
Email 1:
Morning Mr. Smith,                    I need 1500 m3 of crude oil from New York to London by August 1st. Also, what would your demurrage rate be if we’re 15 minutes late?                    Regards,                    James
Email 2:
Hello Mr. Smith,
         I’m working for American Fuel Corporation from New York and I need to receive 250 m3 of crude oil from you on July 25th.
         In addition, what would your demurrage rate be if we’re one hour late? Thanks.
         Regards,
         Lisa
         ----------------------------
         Day 8
         Hi, Lisa,
         Thanks for your email. Please fill in the following blanks and then return to me.
         What is your port name?
         _________________________
         How many m3 of crude oil will you send? 250 m3
         _________________________
         Where is your loading date? July 25th
         _________________________
         What is your discharge port? London
         _________________________
         If the ship is one hour late, how much do you have to pay?
         ______________________
Email 3:
I would like to know that the distance between New York and London by water is around 4550 miles. From your blanks, you will need about 64 hours to reach London if the ship moves 100 miles per day. In this case, we can conclude that if the ship arrives in 65 hours, it will be one hour late.
Regards,
Mark
[Note: It took one day for Mark to give the answer, which took his client only 10 minutes.]

---
This was flagged by email as it was coming from an unknown sender. User profile was inspected and found to be empty. It was sent through Rapid Mailer (Mandrill)

However, it did contain a tracking number to an item that the sender said had been sent from the USA, which has led to this email. So this would likely come from some sort of automated mailer.

The files appear to be some sort of "GET mail spambot" or maybe a B2B mailer system. 
The zip contains a bunch of folders and files, and does not look executable. Likely some user data.

A reply to the first email, from Joe Parr (leadninetwo@gmail.com).

Thank you so much for your quick reply. We're still a bit confused as to how our package ended up in Norway, but at least we know where it is.

Please let us know the next steps. We should be able to collect it asap.


Sincerely,  
Joe Parr

Security scan completed for this email.

Text analysis:

"sent a parcel from the USA that we delivered today"
"can you reply to this email with their next steps?"
"led to this email"

The sender in this email is outside of the comapny, and appears to be a client, so our client may have received the email, but it's probably not their problem.

The second

---

Gabriel

---
From: m.cragie@asahishipping.co.jp

Subject: Re: Steel Scrap Shipment Inquiry - Aqaba to Durban
Timestamp: 2024-04-16 15:30
Body: Dear Mr. Gabriel,

We are happy to arrange the 500MT shipment to Durban. Here are the vessel details:

Ship Name: MV Asahi
ETA Aqaba: 26/4
ETA Durban: 16/5
Type of Ship: Container Vessel
Container Size: 20 & 40 Feet
Container Rate: USD 170.00 x 20 Feet, USD 150.00 x 40 Feet

Please note that the vessel's ETA in Aqaba is subject to cargo release on 26/4. If released on time, cargo should be trucked to port by 27/4. If not released by 26/4, the vessel will depart, and the new ETA will be 29/4, requiring cargo delivery by 28/4.

Best regards,
Margaret Cragie

Timestamp: 2024-01-15 09:30

Lydia

---
From: roberto.deanda@shipping.com
To: lydia.martinez@chemtrade.com
Subject: Re: Shipping Quote Request - Sodium Cyanide La Plata to Trieste
Timestamp: 2024-01-15 11:45
Body: Dear Lydia,

- Safety Data Sheet (SDS)
