Roberto De Anda

Hello Ms. Lim,                    Can your barge lift 3,400 mt of coal from Kuantan to Johor? Also, do you apply a bunker escalation clause or keep a fixed rate?                    Warm regards,                    Paula
Email 2:
From: Kwan Wai Lim, 
                    Ms. [namew@bizsouthasia.com]                    
                    Sent: 3 June 2020 3:24 AM
                    To: Paula Tan [peTan@ch7.com.sg]
                    Subject: RE: Coal barge freight rate from Kuantan to Johor

Hi Paula,

My barge can't lift 3,400 mt of coal. My barge can only carry 1,400 mt.
For freight rate we have three rate contracts, these are for 6 months and 3 months and 1 month. So no fixed rate and no bunker escalation clause.

Best regards,
Kwan Wai Lim
                    Global Sea Trade Pte Ltd

                    7 Scotts Road #14-02 Shaw Centre 228210
                    Tel: (65) 6733 6385 | Fax:

From: annabelle.chen@example.com
To: scarlett.scott@logistics.com
Subject: Waste Plastic Film Shipment - Fuzhou to Tianjin
Timestamp: 2023-07-20 09:15
Body: Dear Mrs. Scott,

We have a 5,000MT shipment of waste plastic film from Fuzhou to Tianjin that will be finished by July 28. What is the best lead time you can offer, and will you be able to cover our last two shipments for $2,500?

Regards,
Annabelle

---
From: scarlett.scott@logistics.com
To: annabelle.chen@example.com
Subject: Re: Waste Plastic Film Shipment - Fuzhou to Tianjin
Timestamp: 2023-07-21 14:30
Body: Dear Ms. Annabelle,

Thank you for your email. We have storage tanks and packing equipment available to accept your 5,000MT shipment of waste plastic film starting July 28. The lead time will be approximately four days for completing the tanking process.

We can handle the loading, stuffing, and lashing, while you will be responsible for fixing and sealing the hatch. Please confirm if the cargo will be using hatch cover or double-containerization so we can prepare accordingly.

Regarding the $2,500 rate for the last two shipments, we cannot accept this condition as terminal handling fees and port storage costs are included in the quoted price. We would need to discuss a rate adjustment.

Best regards,
Scarlett

---
From: annabelle.chen@example.com
To: scarlett.scott@logistics.com
Subject: Re: Waste Plastic Film Shipment - Fuzhou to Tianjin
Timestamp: 2023-07-25 10:45
Body: Dear Ms. Scarlett,

The cargo will be using hatch cover. The cargo from our past three shipments will arrive in Tianjin tomorrow. We expect the same quality as before. Please have the cargo loaded as soon as possible and arrange for delivery to our designated terminal before August 15. If everything goes as expected, we will make arrangements for the second shipment.

Best regards,
Scarlett

---
From: scarlett.scott@logistics.com
To: annabelle.chen@example.com
Subject: Re: Waste Plastic Film Shipment - Fuzhou to Tianjin
Timestamp: 2023-07-27 16:20
Body: Dear Ms. Annabelle,

10 tons of cargo were loaded yesterday, but we still have remaining cargo. Please note that our available forklifts can only lift a maximum of 10 tons at a time. We currently have limited space due to ongoing building works, which affects truck maneuverability around the storage tanks.

Please advise the final loading date required for our storage tanks. We expect the cargo to maintain good condition and hope the terminal waiting time won't affect your schedule.

Regards,
Scarlett

---
From: scarlett.scott@logistics.com
To: annabelle.chen@example.com
Subject: Re: Waste Plastic Film Shipment - Fuzhou to Tianjin
Timestamp: 2023-08-10 09:00
Body: Dear Ms. Annabelle,

Please be advised that the cargo was delivered at 10 a.m. this morning. Our team will monitor the cargo continuously and keep you updated about any movements. We will notify you if we need to deliver the cargo ahead of schedule.

We look forward to our continued business relationship.

Regards,
Scarlett

Email 1:
Nick,

In response to your email, 8,000MT of EVA resin from India to Turkey? No, no, no, we don't have the space, but we are talking about 15,000MT to Taiwan? Yes, yes, yes.

The freight rate? Maybe $10.5, definitely not$11.

<Email 3>:
Email 1:
Nick,

That's good news. 15,000MT of EVA resin from India to Taiwan. It sounds much better.

But we have a problem: I just learned that the customer in Turkey and the customer in Taiwan are the same. It's just a customer's secondary office. I don't think they will need that much EVA resin in both places at the same time. If it's like 15,000MT, I'm afraid they will cancel the order.

Email 2:
Good morning Ms. Klein,                    You made a valid point when you said that ships are very expensive to operate.  So, if we were to provide the food, would that drop the price?                    Your obedient servant,                    Karen
The letter writer is trying to establish the availability of a service from a potential supplier. To do so, she needs to ask questions.
If you choose the service, the supplier may not think that you are interested in the product.  That is why Ms. Klein tells you that ships are expensive to operate and, thus, puts you in a more interested position.  On the other hand, you may not think that the service is suitable for your product.  This is why Ms. Klein suggests that you could provide the food.  In this case, the product is the food.  The product is the basis for the discussion.
Either Ms. Klein

Email 1:
Dear Ms. Ghosh,                    My group is sourcing 25,000MT of rubber from Shanghai to Salem. We can be very flexible on loading, but need to know your thoughts on two possible shipping methods:                    1. 50/50 via Hoegh Autoliner 85 and Maersk Ode. How much extra would be this compared to a typical voyage at your current market price?                    2. 33/67 via Golden Highway and Damleev. Is there any discount available if we book these voyages for 2016 as well?                    Sincerely,                    Sarah
Email 2:
Dear Sarah,                        Glad to get your inquiry. Actually, I have just sent an email regarding the new liner service through Hoegh Autoliner 85 and Maersk Ode to VRS China. Let me know if you get that. I am not sure about the sea transport to India since I am not from that dept. But I would like to go for the FCL rate of Hoegh Autoliner as there is an attractive rate by these carriers.                    One of my friends of Taiwan is also very interested in this carrier. She will go for 10/20 cbm containers. But they were waiting for the government’s final approval. Anyway, please wait for our China dept’s advice.                    Any other queries please contact me at any time.                    Have a nice day!                    Yours faithfully,                    Rita Lee


This email exchange reveals the organizational culture at logistics
Email 3:
Subject: 50/50 via Hoegh Autoliner 85 and Maersk Ode?
Rita,   I got your message about Hoegh Autoliner 85 and Maersk Ode. Thank you for the offer! Do you have any indication on the timing of the service? In addition, do you think I should consider 33/67 via Golden Highway and Damleev as well? I did not include those carriers in the original email because my thinking was that they are more suitable for 2016. Still, the volumes will be the same for both years. Sarah


In this email exchange, Sarah was mainly interested in the future developments of Hoegh Autoliner 85 and Maersk Ode. She also mentioned that she wanted to discuss an alternative carrier, Golden Highway and Damleev.

To: m.albashir@worldholdings.com
Subject: Re: Gasoline Shipment Inquiry - Transaction Details
Timestamp: 2024-01-15 14:45
Body: Dr. Al-Bashir,

We are extremely interested in moving forward with our transaction. We can finance 50% of the $800,000, and we need to know how you will finance the other $400,000. I am prepared to wire you $100,000 towards the transaction on condition that you forward the other $300,000 (and the shipping documents) within 10 days of receiving this deposit.

I understand that this is a small amount relative to the transaction, but I am sending you this deposit on the condition that it will be returned within 14 days if you are not able to complete the transaction.

Best regards,
Raymond

---
From: m.albashir@worldholdings.com
To: raymond.trader@bbridge.com
Subject: Re: Gasoline Shipment Inquiry - Payment Details
Timestamp: 2024-01-16 10:15
Body: Dear Raymond,

I am really sorry for the delay on our side. I was out of the office due to personal reasons for a few days. We have paid all our bills and we have enough funds. I just need your Bank's Swift Code and your Account Number, then we can proceed to making the payment today.

Regards,
Mohammed al-Bashir
Managing Director
World Holdings

---
From: raymond.trader@bbridge.com
To: m.albashir@worldholdings.com
Subject: Re: Gasoline Shipment Inquiry - Fund Transfer

Raymond

---

Regards,
Raymond

From: mona.smith@tradingco.com
To: james.wilson@shipbroker.com
Subject: Freight Quote Request - PKO Port Klang to Male
Timestamp: 2024-02-20 09:15
Body: Hi James,

I have a load of palm kernel oil coming from Port Klang to Male. I'd like to move 5,000MT of oil. I have an email below from a freight forwarder in Port Klang, could you help me out with an indicative freight?

Cheers,
Mona

---
From: james.wilson@shipbroker.com
To: mona.smith@tradingco.com
Subject: Re: Freight Quote Request - PKO Port Klang to Male
Timestamp: 2024-02-20 10:30
Body: Hi Mona,

Thanks for the enquiry. So you are looking for a freight quote to move 5,000MT of palm kernel oil from Port Klang to Male?

I'll need more details about the cargo before I can give you a quote. Could you please let me know:
- The quality and cleanliness of the cargo
- The minimum temperature the cargo must be kept at on board
- If you need a refrigerated vessel
- What type of stowage is required

I'll need to know who will arrange for the stowage, loading, discharge and clearance as this will affect the charges.

Please email all these details to me as soon as you can. Once I have the information, I will be able to provide you with an indicative freight quote.

Looking forward to hearing from you.

Best regards,
James

Sally

---
From: t.armitage@chartering.sg
To: sally.chen@tradeco.com
Subject: Re: Rice Shipment Singapore-Jakarta Inquiry
Timestamp: 2023-11-11 14:30
Body: Dear Sally,

Tony Armitage

---
From: t.armitage@chartering.sg
To: sally.chen@tradeco.com

Please advise if you would like to proceed by 15 Nov at the latest.

Regards,
Tony

From: nana.smith@company.com
To: dan.miller@shipping.com
Subject: Coal Shipment Booking Request - Santos to Sibenik
Timestamp: 2024-01-15 09:30
Body: Dear Dan,

Please book our 3,000 metric tons of shipment for coal in Santos, Brazil to Sibenik, Croatia.

Thanks,
Nana

---
From: dan.miller@shipping.com
To: nana.smith@company.com
Subject: Re: Coal Shipment Booking Request - Santos to Sibenik
Timestamp: 2024-01-15 10:15
Body: Dear Nana,

Thank you for the information. I will book the shipment. I just have a question regarding the cargo distribution.

Aare, could you please provide the details on how this shipment should be handled?

Best regards,
Dan

---
From: aare.johnson@logistics.com
To: dan.miller@shipping.com
Subject: Re: Coal Shipment Booking Request - Santos to Sibenik
Timestamp: 2024-01-15 11:00
Body: Hi Dan,

Regarding the 3,000 tons of coal shipment, it will be split as follows:
- 1,500 tons for port handling
- 1,500 tons for bill of lading

Best regards,
Aare

---
From: dan.miller@shipping.com
To: aare.johnson@logistics.com
Subject: Re: Coal Shipment Booking Request - Santos to Sibenik
Timestamp: 2024-01-15 11:45
Body: Hello Aare,

I found out that a port will take 1,500 metric tons of coal in this transaction. It's a standard amount for the port. Would you mind giving us more information about the second half of the bill of lading?

Thanks,
Dan

---
From: aare.johnson@logistics.com
To: dan.miller@shipping.com
Subject: Re: Coal Shipment Booking Request - Santos to Sibenik
Timestamp: 2024-01-15 12:30
Body: Hello Dan,

Thank you for reaching out. As for the bill of lading, it's the same amount as the port. It's just the way we handle cargo. Our ships move very fast, so we need the cargo to be in the same condition as the first half of the bill of lading.

Best regards,
Aare

Email 1:
Hi Ms. Li,                    We have a cargo of 6,000MT to be loaded in Malabo. It must be delivered in Cape Town by 11 May. Would your company be interested in tendering?                    Thanks,                    Kris
Email 2:
Subject: Re: (RE: TENDER FOR 6000MT MALABO TO CAPE TOWN)                    Thanks for your inquiry. Our rate for this shipment is USD1,500.                    Looking forward to your reply.

Answer 1:
Subject: RE: (RE: TENDER FOR 6000MT MALABO TO CAPE TOWN)                    The rate is okay with us, but there is a problem with the transit time. Could you check your ETA for my customer? We are willing to pay more, if it will arrive earlier. Thanks

Answer 2:
Dear Alice,                    Unfortunately, we are not sure if we can achieve the ETA. Our vessel has a good speed, but if it is ballast in Malabo, it will take at least 16 days. If the cargo is loaded in Malabo, it will have to wait for our ship
output_text:
From: claudio.martinez@trading.com
To: paul.wilson@broker.com
Subject: Competitor Pricing - Hamburg/Singapore Route
Timestamp: 2024-01-15 09:23
Body: Hi Paul,

We heard that our competitors are in the market to ship 9,000 barrels of refined product from Hamburg to Singapore. Do you know their fixing level?

Regards,
Claudio

---
From: paul.wilson@broker.com
To: claudio.martinez@trading.com
Subject: Re: Competitor Pricing - Hamburg/Singapore Route
Timestamp: 2024-01-15 10:45
Body: Dear Claudio,

As per my knowledge, those competitors I have worked with in the past in Germany are fixing at USD 30 above market. However, they are very difficult to deal with.

Regards,
Paul

---
From: john.smith@trading.com
To: claudio.martinez@trading.com
Subject: Re: Competitor Pricing - Hamburg/Singapore Route
Timestamp: 2024-01-15 11:30
Body: Claudio,

Do you know their plans for February?

They are asking USD 30/Barrel above market for January delivery.

Regards,
John

---
From: claudio.martinez@trading.com
To: john.smith@trading.com
Subject: Re: Competitor Pricing - Hamburg/Singapore Route
Timestamp: 2024-01-15 12:15
Body: Hi John,

You got it. They are holding their views and intend to continue with their own price fixing.

Regards,
Claudio

---
From: john.smith@trading.com
To: claudio.martinez@trading.com
Subject: Re: Competitor Pricing - Hamburg/Singapore Route
Timestamp: 2024-01-15 12:45
Body: Claudio,

That's interesting. Could you tell me anything more about them? What makes them different from others?

Regards,
John

---
From: claudio.martinez@trading.com
To: john.smith@trading.com
Subject: Re: Competitor Pricing - Hamburg/Singapore Route
Timestamp: 2024-01-15 13:20
Body: Hi John,

They are absolutely different from the rest of the players in the market. They are very conservative and they are not satisfied with the current low margins.

Regards,
Claudio

From: erik.hansen@shipbroker.com
To: k.nakayama@portauthority.com
Subject: SP33 Tanker - Berthing Request Exception
Timestamp: 2024-02-14 08:15
Body: Dear Ms. Nakayama,

The tanker SP33 was scheduled to arrive this morning at 7am, but she could not berth because of the insufficient ship's hook capacity. As a result, she will have to stay at anchorage until the next high tide.

Could you make an exception and let her berth?

Thank you very much,
Erik

---
From: k.nakayama@portauthority.com
To: erik.hansen@shipbroker.com
Subject: Re: SP33 Tanker - Berthing Request Exception
Timestamp: 2024-02-14 09:30
Body: Dear Erik,

With regard to the SP33, as the berthing hook capacity is insufficient, I'm afraid we cannot accept her today. This is a safety requirement that we cannot waive.

Sorry for the inconvenience.

Regards,
Kim

Timestamp: 2024-05-26 09:30
Body: Dear Monica Zhang,

This email was sent to you by Hopa Freight (Part of the Shipyaari Group) as you have been pre-screened to be of interest in the freight market.

We invite you to explore our services and comprehensive freight solutions. Please visit our FAQ section for information on what to expect when you book with us, including details about our innovative freight buying model and how it differs from traditional approaches.

Useful Links:
- What to Expect When Booking
- FAQ Page
- Privacy Policy

Hopa Freight Marketing Team

To: monica.zhang@gmail.com
Subject: RE: Broker Agreement for China Export Services
Timestamp: 2024-05-26 14:45
Body: Dear Monica Zhang,

Thank you for your request. I am attaching our Broker Agreement to this email. If you are in agreement with our terms of service, please sign and return it to us by email.

I notice from your feedback that you are interested in exporting freight to China. Once I receive the signed copy of our terms, I will assign a dedicated Broker to handle your requirements.

As a European-based company, we also handle freight to various European destinations through our extensive network of agents. We can accommodate all your international transport needs.

I look forward to working with you.

Cheers,
Phil McBride
Hopa Freight

output_text:
From: ben.walker@tradingco.com
To: j.sterling@sterlingship.com
Subject: Diesel Shipment Quote Request - Singapore to Savannah
Timestamp: 2024-01-15 09:30
Body: Hi Mr. Sterling,

Would you give me a quote for shipping 13,000MT of diesel from Singapore to Savannah, Georgia?

Also, do you typically allow free discharge time?

Thanks,
Ben

---
From: j.sterling@sterlingship.com
To: ben.walker@tradingco.com
Subject: Re: Diesel Shipment Quote Request - Singapore to Savannah
Timestamp: 2024-01-15 11:45
Body: Dear Ben,

To provide you with an accurate quote, I need some additional information:

- Do you have 13,000MT ready to ship in one lot or in smaller lots?
- What vessel type are you shipping with?
- What is the quantity in one shipment?
- Is this 1 shipment or a continuous cargo?
- Is this contract or spot charter?
- Will the cargo be drummed or bulk?
- Do you need an L/C or are you paying with cash?
- Would you like to have C&F or FOB rates?
- When is the earliest that the cargo can be shipped?
- Would you like to have a freight guarantee?

Regards,
John Sterling

---
From: ben.walker@tradingco.com
To: j.sterling@sterlingship.com
Subject: Re: Diesel Shipment Quote Request - Singapore to Savannah
Timestamp: 2024-01-15 14:20
Body: Hi John,

Here are the details:

- We have 8,000-12,000MT ready to ship immediately, and 13,000MT ready within 3 weeks
- Planning to use a 75,000MT T1 Double Hull Tanker
- Shipments will be between 8,000-12,000MT at a time
- This will be continuous shipments, one trip at a time
- Looking for a contract charter

Best regards,
Ben

From: davina.smith@automakerxyz.com
To: m.wong@carlogistics.com
Subject: Car Transport Services - Jakarta to Gioia Tauro
Timestamp: 2024-02-10 09:15
Body: Dear Mr. Wong,

Our client, Automaker XYZ, is considering the port of Gioia Tauro for handling their Toyota Camry cars from Jakarta to Italy. We would like to know whether you have experience moving cars from Jakarta.

Regards,
Davina

---
From: m.wong@carlogistics.com
To: davina.smith@automakerxyz.com
Subject: Re: Car Transport Services - Jakarta to Gioia Tauro
Timestamp: 2024-02-11 14:30
Body: Dear Davina,

Our company has been moving cars from Jakarta to Gioia Tauro for more than ten years, our most recent contract has just expired, and we are looking for a new contract. The cars are transported by sea and sent on special carriers that go from Jakarta to Genoa and from there by rail to Gioia Tauro. On average, 250 cars are moved each year.

We look forward to cooperating with you and await a favorable answer from you.

Regards,
Massimo

---
From: davina.smith@automakerxyz.com
To: m.wong@carlogistics.com
Subject: Re: Car Transport Services - Jakarta to Gioia Tauro
Timestamp: 2024-02-12 10:45
Body: Dear Massimo,

I must say we are impressed with your quality of service. Your fleet is not the largest on the market, but we have found that smaller companies often provide a higher quality service. We can therefore look forward to working with you and hope that we can build a long-term relationship.

Regards,
Davina

output_text:
From: john.developer@techcorp.com
To: support@angularteam.com
Subject: Question about Angular Forms Module Implementation
Timestamp: 2024-01-15 09:23
Body: Hi Angular Support Team,

I'm having some issues implementing email validation in our Angular application. Could you provide guidance on the proper way to handle email input validation?

Best regards,
John

---
From: support@angularteam.com
To: john.developer@techcorp.com
Subject: Re: Question about Angular Forms Module Implementation
Timestamp: 2024-01-15 10:45
Body: Hi John,

For email validation in Angular 2+, you'll need to:

1. Import FormsModule using: import { FormsModule } from '@angular/forms'
2. Add FormsModule to the imports array in your @NgModule declaration: imports: [ BrowserModule, FormsModule ]
3. Add [email] to your input tag

Let me know if you need any clarification.

Best,
Angular Support Team

---
From: john.developer@techcorp.com
To: support@angularteam.com
Subject: Re: Question about Angular Forms Module Implementation
Timestamp: 2024-01-15 11:30
Body: Thanks for the quick response!

I implemented the changes as suggested. The FormsModule integration was indeed quite straightforward. At the end of the day, it was more trivial than I expected.

Appreciate your help!

Best regards,
John

From: maria.flippo@abc-corp.com
To: jason.mcgroarty@rbccm.com
Subject: Asset Transfer Agreement Review
Timestamp: 2004-12-14 09:30
Body: Dear Mr. McGroarty,

I am writing regarding the pending asset transfer agreement between ABC and RBC Capital Markets. We would like to schedule a review of the proposed terms with our Board of Directors.

Kind regards,
Maria Flippo

---
From: jason.mcgroarty@rbccm.com
To: maria.flippo@abc-corp.com
Subject: Re: Asset Transfer Agreement Review
Timestamp: 2004-12-15 11:45
Body: Dear Ms. Flippo,

I appreciate your email dated December 14th. We are still analyzing our options and have reached no final conclusion. The timing of our acquisition of the remaining 15% is part of that analysis. In the meantime, the rest of our business remains as before and the Board of Directors of ABC will continue to oversee its management.

RBC Capital Markets
Jason McGroarty
(416) 842-6293

---
From: jason.mcgroarty@rbccm.com
To: maria.flippo@abc-corp.com
Subject: RE: Asset Transfer - Deposit Notice
Timestamp: 2004-12-16 14:20
Body: Dear Ms. Flippo,

I was copied on your email yesterday to Mr. Frank and Messrs. Calloway and Vaughn. Please be advised that pursuant to Section 14.4 of the Purchase Agreement dated November 4, 2004, we have placed certain assets that are subject to the asset transfer agreement in our depository at 15 York St., Toronto, to await return to ABC. These assets are detailed in the list attached to our email of December 14, 2004 (see attachment A). I assume these are the assets under your custody. Please advise if you have any objections to this deposit.

---
From: maria.flippo@abc-corp.com
To: jason.mcgroarty@rbccm.com
Subject: Re: Asset Transfer - Deposit Notice
Timestamp: 2004-12-16 16:45
Body: Dear Mr. McGroarty,

Thank you for your email. While we have no objections to the list provided, it has not been previously reviewed by ABC's Board of Directors. The list appears to conflict with the Sale Agreement requirements, particularly regarding retention of files and ABC Confidential Information. Your proposal to place our assets in a depository pending return is inappropriate and contrary to the terms of the Sale Agreement, specifically Section 2.1(a).

---
From: frank.thompson@rbccm.com
To: jason.mcgroarty@rbccm.com
Subject: Re: Asset Transfer Concerns
Timestamp: 2004-12-17 10:30
Body: I just spoke with Martin but I was copied on the email below. Today is December 17th, 2004 and we continue to have no approved and executed sale agreement. In the meantime, ABC is purging all of our assets and information, and sending same to various unidentified third parties and law firms. We simply cannot accept these proposals in light of ABC's wrongful purging of our assets. All of the discussion contained in your email is irrelevant in light of the purging. Please provide us with a confirmed list of all assets that have been sent to third parties and their names.

---
From: maria.flippo@abc-corp.com
To: jason.mcgroarty@rbccm.com
Subject: Re: Asset Transfer Concerns
Timestamp: 2004-12-17 11:15
Body: Dear Mr. McGroarty,

You must withdraw any claim that ABC has breached the purchase agreement. You are not our trading partner; you are our custodian, holding assets that belong to ABC until such time as the transaction is closed.

From: christa.mueller@logisticsco.com
To: hugo.gonzales@shipline.com
Subject: Rotterdam-Naples Container Contract Review
Timestamp: 2024-02-20 09:15
Body: Good morning Mr. Gonzales,

Our team has been reviewing the contract for freight containers between Rotterdam and Naples for some weeks now.

Do you have any further business questions or suggestions to our market analysis?

Regards,
Christa

---
From: hugo.gonzales@shipline.com
To: christa.mueller@logisticsco.com
Subject: Re: Rotterdam-Naples Container Contract Review
Timestamp: 2024-02-20 09:45
Body: Morning Christa,

If I remember correctly, that contract included only containers shipped by steam ship, but I now know that steam ships have been phased out in favor of modern container ships.

I'd like to amend that contract to cover all types of modern container ships, with a specific expiration date.

Regards,
Hugo

---
From: christa.mueller@logisticsco.com
To: hugo.gonzales@shipline.com
Subject: Re: Rotterdam-Naples Container Contract Review
Timestamp: 2024-02-20 10:30
Body: Hi Hugo,

I've found some documentation from the 1970s that shows there was still a significant number of containers transported by steam ship, despite being a less economical transportation method.

What do you think about this historical context?

Regards,
Christa

---
From: hugo.gonzales@shipline.com
To: christa.mueller@logisticsco.com
Subject: Re: Rotterdam-Naples Container Contract Review
Timestamp: 2024-02-20 11:00
Body: Hi Christa,

That is no doubt true. However, steam ships proved extremely dangerous for the containers, even the newest ones. The vibrations produced by the steam engines, and the leaks from the boilers, caused significant damage to most containers in transit. This is precisely why modern container ships have completely replaced them.

Regards,
Hugo

• Have you developed any Java GUI applications?
• What IDE do you use to develop Java GUIs?

• Have you developed any projects in C/C++?

HR Team

Email 3:

[Letter of understanding and agreement.][which will I assume be applied to container ships and not to other vessels such as your DWT which sail through. It's not my fault.]  Since the signing of the Neutrality

Treaty between the United States of America and the Republic of Panama of 1926, the Panama Canal has been operated as an interoceanic highway in a manner which has been equitable and impartial to all the merchant vessels of all nations, and in a manner consistent with the operation of other interoceanic waterways. The tolls for the use of the waterway have been established in the Treaty at rates which

would be consistent with the tolls charged to vessels

From: maersk.operations@maersk.com
To: scott.anderson@company.com
Subject: Maersk confirms opening of new Singapore-Yantian-Busan-Vladivostok service
Timestamp: 2017-05-15 09:30
Body: Hey Scott,

Happy to inform you that we have received the Maersk announcement on the new SINGAPORE - YANTIAN - BUSAN - VLADIVOSTOK service.

This is a new direct import & export service to Busan and Vladivostok from Yantian, operating on a full-weekly schedule. Service is targeted to start May 2017.

Vessel: MV MAERSK SOUTH WALES

Initial schedule as follows:
YM - Yantian Wednesday (port stay two days)
YB - Yantian Thursday (port stay two days)
YS - Yantian Saturday (port stay two days)
YV - Yantian Monday (port stay two days)

Detailed schedule to Busan and Vladivostok will follow.

Best regards

---
From: maersk.operations@maersk.com
To: partners@distribution.list
Subject: RE: Updated Schedule - New Yantian-Busan-Vladivostok Service
Timestamp: 2017-05-16 14:15
Body: Dear Partners,

Thank you for your feedback regarding our new YANTIAN - BUSAN - VLADIVOSTOK service. Please find the confirmed first sailings schedule:

YM - dep Yantian Wed 24/5 ETA Busan 31/5 ETA Vladivostok 05/06
YB - dep Yantian Thu 25/5 ETA Busan 01/6 ETA Vladivostok 05/06

Weekly port calls remain as previously advised:
YM - Yantian Wednesday (port stay two days)
YB - Yantian Thursday (port stay two days)
YS - Yantian Saturday (port stay two days)
YV - Yantian Monday (port stay two days)

Best regards

Fergus

In any dialogue it is important to state facts and not omit or conceal important information. This gives room for miscommunication as well as mistrust between the two sides. That’s why it is important to understand how to communicate professionally in business correspondence.

## What is Business Correspondence?

A message sent and received via a written form is known as a business correspondence. It is crucial as it provides information on the various activities of an organization. There are several forms of business correspondence. They include formal business letters, e-mails, and memos.

The letter types might be used to communicate with customers, clients, or employees. Some examples of business correspondence include application letters

From: johannah.zabcjok@cobexmarine.com.au
To: zohair@company.com
Subject: FERT Price Update and Offer
Timestamp: 2023-10-15 09:30
Body: Greetings Zohair,

FYI: The price of FERT today is 2875/2845 with the last done deal at 2870 for 6000mt x 4mth fixed delivered to Tubarao.

Recent market activity:
- 2865 for 6000mt (Oct 5)
- 2855 for 5500mt (Oct 8)
- 2850 for 6000mt (Oct 10)
- 2860 for 5800mt (Oct 12)
- 2870 for 6000mt (Oct 14)

As these deals were made well in time, we believe the market is on the rise. We would like to confirm our offer at 2770.

Please confirm if you are agreeable to our offer. If we don't hear from you, we will assume your acceptance.

Regards,
Johannah Zabcjok

---
From: zohair@company.com
To: johannah.zabcjok@cobexmarine.com.au
Subject: Re: FERT Price Update and Offer
Timestamp: 2023-10-15 14:45
Body: Thanks for the update,

In reference to our email regarding your offer of 2770:

You confirmed to us that your sales team confirmed the deals in place were between 2845 to 2870 for the 1st of November delivery. Yet you are demanding we confirm your offer of 2770.

I am not sure why this is so, but it is clear the market price is closer to 2870. At this point, we would rather make our arrangements for 1st of Nov delivery when we know the market has risen, rather than when it is sitting at its low.

Please advise what exactly you expect from us.

Sincerely,
Zohair

---
From: johannah.zabcjok@cobexmarine.com.au

Subject: Re: FERT Price Update and Offer

Johannah

---

Johannah Zabcjok

From: yang.jun@military.cn
To: liming.yang@gmail.com
Subject: Reaching out after 6 years
Timestamp: 2023-11-01 14:23
Body: Hey Mom,

It's been 6 years since we saw each other. Are you still in Hong Kong? I am now a captain in the army. I can't believe how fast the time has gone by.

Best regards,
Jun

---
From: liming.yang@gmail.com
To: yang.jun@military.cn
Subject: Re: Reaching out after 6 years
Timestamp: 2023-11-02 09:15
Body: Dear Captain Yang,

I was glad to get your email. Yes, I am still in Hong Kong, but I will be moving to Beijing soon. Please don't worry. I am very well, and I hope you are as well. Now you can tell me about your life. Where are you stationed? And where are your wife and children? How old are they?

Love,
Mom

---
From: yang.jun@military.cn
To: liming.yang@gmail.com
Subject: Re: Reaching out after 6 years
Timestamp: 2023-11-03 18:42
Body: Hi Mom,

I am glad that you are still doing well. My family is fine. My children are getting bigger. My oldest is almost 6 years old, and my youngest is 4. I will have to wait a little longer until I can send you pictures of them. I am stationed near Guangzhou. My wife and I don't see each other very often, so I guess you could say that we are basically divorced.

Take care,
Jun

Regards,
Anders

Thanks for your mail, we are happy to discuss lumpsum deals. Our vessel, the MV Khaleej is currently on charter in Galveston, Texas. We could ship 7,000MT of refined crude oil for an FOB price of USD 55 million from Port Lagos. There are only two conditions:

Mr. Jimmie Jones

Hi Jeremy,                   Thank you for the detailed information. The Port of Elizabeth is basically a bit “rustic”. Most of the coal is stored at berths which are up the hill or out of the water in a kind of side-loading facility. The coal berths are essentially ash ponds that are filled from barges, loaded from stockpiles, or loaded by rail. In any case, the coal must be transported in some way and the loading will depend on the coal berth. The average loading rate is between 600-800 mt/h, and with no draft restrictions or berthing limitations, we are expected to load at an average rate of 1500 mt/h. We can also do up to 2,000 mt/h if the coal can be delivered to the berth quickly and easily.

Be advised that in March, the water in the port will be very low. Because of

<Email 4>:
 * As per point 2, we will provide that discharging of cargo be from full cargo vessel's cargo tanks to cargo or bunker barge's empty tanks, and that as long as cargo vessel's tanks are constantly filled, full loaded vessel shall remain alongside bunkering and/or cargo barge throughout the bunkering/discharging operation.

                       *The cargo vessel to be of chemical tanker type  or similar design, capable of maintaining a barge alongside its own side for discharge in a full laden condition for up to a total of 24 hours. From: richard.vernon@vernonshipping.com
To: jin.chen@chenlines.com
Subject: Vessel Inquiry - Iron Ore Transport Dampier to Yuan Island
Timestamp: 2011-08-05 09:30
Body: Dear Ms. Chen,

We have urgent need for a vessel, 50,000dwt size, with good dry-bulk and/or ore carrier experience for transportation of between 20,000 and 25,000 MT of iron ore from Dampier to Yuan Island.

Please confirm your vessel's availability, draft and size, and also availability of existing ballast water. When can you have your vessel at sea, and does it accept 'dumping' of cargo in the event of strike?

We would be most grateful if you could provide a detailed specification of your vessel, including crew, safety records, and insurance policy information, by 7th August.

We will contact you regarding further details after this date.

Yours faithfully,
Richard Vernon

---
From: jin.chen@chenlines.com
To: richard.vernon@vernonshipping.com
Subject: Re: Vessel Inquiry - Iron Ore Transport Dampier to Yuan Island
Timestamp: 2011-08-06 14:15
Body: Dear Mr. Vernon,

Thank you for your enquiry.

We are pleased to inform you that we have an 87,000dwt ocean-going ore carrier on our register. The vessel is 12 years old and has passed rigorous safety inspections. She has been chartered to an oil company for the past 3 months and is now available from 15th August.

In the event of a strike, the vessel has the capability of 'dumping' her cargo.

We would be most grateful if you would advise the load port, discharge port, estimated cargo quantity, loading time, and estimated number of loading/discharging crew.

Yours faithfully,
Jin Chen

---
From: richard.vernon@vernonshipping.com
To: jin.chen@chenlines.com
Subject: Re: Vessel Inquiry - Iron Ore Transport Dampier to Yuan Island
Timestamp: 2011-08-08 10:45
Body: Dear Mr. Chen,

Thank you for your swift reply.

With your permission, I enclose an outline of the proposed charter, which covers the period 10th September to 31st October 2011. In addition, I enclose a Letter of Inquiry, which we have requested from Dampier Iron Ore and from Port Walling.

I would be grateful if you would check these and advise on any corrections that you require.

Yours faithfully,
Richard Vernon

---
From: jin.chen@chenlines.com
To: richard.vernon@vernonshipping.com

Timestamp: 2011-08-09 16:30
Body: Dear Richard,

I have reviewed your letter, and I confirm that our vessel will be ready at sea by 15th August, so your preferred dates are acceptable.

With regard to the charter, the only changes that I require are the amounts and unit prices for port, light, and insurance; and the percentage of each these that are to be deducted from the charter.

I trust that these amendments will be acceptable to you. I will revert with confirmation and insurance policy documents once we have both agreed on the terms.

Yours faithfully,
Jin Chen

---
From: richard.vernon@vernonshipping.com
To: jin.chen@chenlines.com
Subject: Re: Vessel Inquiry - Iron Ore Transport Dampier to Yuan Island
Timestamp: 2011-08-10 11:20
Body: Dear Mr. Chen,

The amendments to the charter agreement are acceptable to me. I enclose a signed copy of the charter agreement, together with a draft insurance policy.

I would be most grateful if you could confirm that the vessel is ready for loading by 17th August.

Yours faithfully,
Richard Vernon

From: anne.smith@shippingco.com
To: don.jones@carrierline.com
Subject: Shoe Shipment Rotterdam to Boston
Timestamp: 2024-03-15 09:30
Body: Hello Mr. Jones,

We are looking to ship 1,100MT of shoes from Rotterdam to Boston. Can you confirm your earliest available sail date, and can you let me know if you have a regular schedule?

Kind regards,
Anne

---
From: don.jones@carrierline.com
To: anne.smith@shippingco.com
Subject: Re: Shoe Shipment Rotterdam to Boston
Timestamp: 2024-03-15 11:45
Body: Anne,

We would be happy to help with your shipment. Our regular weekly sailing is on the 23rd of the month. This shipment will sail on the 25th of March. Please confirm your delivery address and let me know if you have any further questions.

Best regards,
Don

---
From: anne.smith@shippingco.com
To: don.jones@carrierline.com
Subject: Re: Shoe Shipment Rotterdam to Boston
Timestamp: 2024-03-15 14:20
Body: Hi Don,

Yes, I think that works for us. The final destination for the goods will be Boston, MA. We will be clearing the goods through Port Newark, NJ.

Thank you for your help!
Anne

---
From: anne.smith@shippingco.com
To: don.jones@carrierline.com
Subject: Re: Shoe Shipment Rotterdam to Boston
Timestamp: 2024-03-16 10:15
Body: Hi Don,

I'm following up about the shipping to Boston, MA. I spoke with our customs broker who said they will need to ship from NJ. Can you let me know if that will be a problem?

Thanks,
Anne

---
From: don.jones@carrierline.com
To: anne.smith@shippingco.com
Subject: Re: Shoe Shipment Rotterdam to Boston
Timestamp: 2024-03-16 11:30
Body: Hi Anne,

NJ is not a problem. The vessel leaves from Rotterdam, then stops in Houston and NJ, before going to Boston. The final destination for the cargo is Boston, and you will clear the cargo in Boston, so that is fine.

Please let me know if you have any further questions.

Don

---
From: ed.wilson@carrierline.com
To: anne.smith@shippingco.com
Subject: Re: Shoe Shipment Rotterdam to Boston
Timestamp: 2024-03-16 15:45
Body: Anne,

The carrier for this shipment will be ZIM Lines. They will export from Rotterdam, and stop in Houston, before sailing to Boston. All shipments are delivered FCA (Free Carrier). This means the carrier will deliver the cargo at their warehouse in Rotterdam, from where you will be responsible for paying for the cargo and the customs duties. You will also be responsible for unloading the cargo, or arranging for that to be done.

Please let me know if you have any further questions.

Regards,
Ed

---
From: don.jones@carrierline.com
To: anne.smith@shippingco.com
Subject: Re: Shoe Shipment Rotterdam to Boston
Timestamp: 2024-03-17 09:00
Body: Anne,

Can you please let me know if you have any questions about our quote? We've already run out of our weekly quota, so we will have to sell your cargo at market price.

Regards,
Don

Email 1:
Good day Mr. Xing,                    I have a cargo of 4,000MT of methanol from Corpus Christi to Durban. Can you send a charter cost, and how much for commission?                    Many thanks,                    Fabio
Email 2:
Good day,                        I would like to know if your company has anything going to Asia to book a chartered vessel. I have 2500mt of steel.                    I am looking forward to hearing from you as soon as possible.                    Kind regards,                    Hennie
Email 3:
Dear Sirs,                         I am a buyer with a cargo of 12,500 MT of steel products from Vietnam. I would like to check your company’s capability in providing Vessel Charter.                    Best regards,                    Cindy

They show up in email. When you google “ur5 quickbooks” and “quickbooks error 176109”, you’ll find this email. They are low cost replicas of your computer’s typical shipping and air delivery errors. One reason why they’re so effective is because they’re 100% human-friendly, like “Q: When will the goods arrive? A: Today.”

When you send them back, they’ll respond. These two replies will let you know that someone from them (and not a computer, and certainly not an imposter) is in your inbox.

If you’re not going to send them a reply, or if you’re going to turn
Email 4:
Dear Sirs,                     I am a buyer with a cargo of 12,500 MT of steel products from Vietnam. I would like to check your company’s capability in providing Vessel Charter.                    Best regards,                    Cindy

Michelle

Cargo Details:
- Volume: 2800 MTS

Ahmed Karim

Mike Evans

Answer: To plan for the arrival and preparation of the cargo.

Best regards,
Joseline

---
From: joseline.martinez@freightco.com
To: lacey.thompson@company.com
Subject: Re: Freight Quote Request - Montevideo to Isla Margarita
Timestamp: 2023-06-20 11:30
Body: Hi Lacey,

I'm following up regarding the shipment from Montevideo to the Vargas Free Zone (Isla Margarita, Venezuela). We've identified that your current freight forwarder is utilizing passenger vessels at premium rates.

We can offer an alternative solution using the MS Francy, which typically operates between Brazil and Venezuela. The vessel was recently chartered by a Dubai-based tour operator who has partnered with us for logistics support.

I've attached the detailed quotation for your review.

Best regards,
Joseline

---
From: joseline.martinez@freightco.com
To: lacey.thompson@company.com
Subject: Re: Freight Quote Request - Updated Schedule
Timestamp: 2023-06-21 15:45
Body: Hi Lacey,

Regarding yesterday's quotation, I wanted to provide additional details. The voyage is scheduled to depart on July 22nd with an estimated arrival on July 25th in Isla Margarita. We recommend using 20' pallets rather than containers to optimize costs. The Dubai operator will contact you directly with additional details.

Best regards,
Joseline

---
From: joseline.martinez@freightco.com
To: lacey.thompson@company.com
Subject: Re: Freight Quote Request - Revised Schedule and Options
Timestamp: 2023-06-23 10:20
Body: Hi Lacey,

I need to inform you that the previously mentioned voyage is now fully booked. However, we've arranged an alternative cargo vessel departing from Valparaiso on July 24th, arriving in Isla Margarita on July 27th. 

We recommend using either 20' flat racks (pallets) for deck loading or truck transport in the vessel's hold, which would be the most cost-effective solution for your cargo.

Please let me know if you'd like a quote for this new arrangement.

Best regards,
Joseline

From: jorge.martinez@acmecorp.com
To: rob.wilson@brooker.com
Subject: Potential Acquisition Discussion
Timestamp: 2024-01-15 09:30
Body: Rob,

I've heard rumors that you are in talks to merge with Brooker Inc. We at our company have been following your success for a while now, and we're very interested in potentially acquiring your brokerage. I believe you could be an excellent addition to our organization.

Would you be open to discussing this opportunity?

Best regards,
Jorge

---
From: rob.wilson@brooker.com
To: jorge.martinez@acmecorp.com
Subject: Re: Potential Acquisition Discussion
Timestamp: 2024-01-15 14:45
Body: Jorge,

Thank you for your interest. I'd be happy to explore this possibility. Could you send me more information about your company and what you envision for this potential acquisition?

Regards,
Rob

---
From: jorge.martinez@acmecorp.com
To: rob.wilson@brooker.com
Subject: Re: Potential Acquisition Discussion
Timestamp: 2024-01-16 10:15
Body: Rob,

I will have our brokerage agreement drafted and sent to you within the next 3 days. We haven't discussed compensation yet, but I'm confident we can find terms that work for both parties.

Thanks for your prompt reply.

Best regards,
Jorge

Sent from my iPad

---
From: rob.wilson@brooker.com
To: jorge.martinez@acmecorp.com
Subject: Re: Potential Acquisition Discussion
Timestamp: 2024-01-16 15:30
Body: Jorge,

Regarding compensation, could you give me an idea of what kind of fee structure you're considering? I'd like to ensure we're working toward a mutually beneficial arrangement.

Also, I'm curious about your assessment of the local market conditions. We've been hearing concerns about a potential market correction in the near future.

Best regards,
Rob

---
From: jorge.martinez@acmecorp.com
To: rob.wilson@brooker.com
Subject: Re: Potential Acquisition Discussion
Timestamp: 2024-01-17 11:00
Body: Rob,

I've reviewed the numbers again, and while they're not quite where we'd like them to be, I still see great potential in this deal. As an alternative approach, I could come in as a silent partner initially, with the option to complete a full buyout later.

Could you share more detailed financial data for our first proper evaluation? I'm looking for a structure that ensures mutual benefit, not just increased sales figures.

Thanks again,
Jorge

From: susanna.bennett@tradingco.com
To: jack.marshall@shippingline.com
Subject: Iron Ore Shipment Inquiry - Virginia to Turkey
Timestamp: 2024-02-01 14:23
Body: Hi Jack,

I'm trying to secure a spot for 20,000 MT of iron ore from Virginia to Turkey. After-hours berthing is an option, but we're flexible. Could you get back to me with some options for the next week and next month?

Thanks,
Susanna

---
From: susanna.bennett@tradingco.com
To: jack.marshall@shippingline.com
Subject: Re: Iron Ore Shipment Inquiry - Virginia to Turkey
Timestamp: 2024-02-02 09:15
Body: Just to follow up, we're still in need of options from Turkey. What do you suggest for a daily service to Turkey, starting next week? This is urgent.

---
From: jack.marshall@shippingline.com
To: susanna.bennett@tradingco.com
Subject: Re: Iron Ore Shipment Inquiry - Virginia to Turkey
Timestamp: 2024-02-02 11:30
Body: Dear Susanna,

Our liners operate out of Virginia, Houston and Long Beach, and to Istanbul, İzmir, Kütahya, and Antalya. We also have a weekly direct service to İzmir from Savannah. It's a fast service, taking about 14 days from loading in the US to discharging in Turkey. If you're interested in shipping from Houston, it's an 11 day trip to Antalya.

All of these routes can be served from one of our 3 weekly services. For a monthly schedule, please visit our website. We don't accept individual bookings, so you would need to find a freight forwarder or consolidator to place your booking.

Regards,
Jack

From: ivy.chen@tradeco.com
To: owen.martin@shipbroker.com
Subject: Shipping Query - Milk Powder & Grain from Sydney to Tokyo
Timestamp: 2023-06-25 09:15
Body: Hello Owen,

Our Australian customer wants to ship some powdered milk from Port Botany in Sydney to Tokyo. The contract says 2,500MT, but they might also require 1,500MT of grain. This order will need to leave in the first week of July.

How much would shipping 4,000MT of both goods together cost, and do you see any risk of port congestion?

Many thanks,
Ivy

---
From: owen.martin@shipbroker.com
To: ivy.chen@tradeco.com
Subject: Re: Shipping Query - Milk Powder & Grain from Sydney to Tokyo
Timestamp: 2023-06-25 14:30
Body: Hi Ivy,

The order for 2,500MT should be manageable. However, regarding the combined shipment with 1,500MT of grain, we cannot find a vessel available to accommodate both cargoes together. While there are still some free slots in July, the total order size limits our options.

We can offer to fit 1,000MT of milk powder and 1,500MT of grain on a 10,000dwt vessel that will complete its previous cargo discharge in July. The vessel details are:

M/V T1
Type: General Cargo
Flag: Liberia
Call Sign: MOYO
Deadweight: 8,600MT
Built: 1996

Best regards,
Owen

---
From: owen.martin@shipbroker.com
To: ivy.chen@tradeco.com
Subject: Re: Shipping Query - Milk Powder & Grain from Sydney to Tokyo
Timestamp: 2023-06-25 14:45
Body: Ivy,

I should add that port congestion in Australia is worsening, and securing a slot for such a large order may be challenging. The railway terminals are also experiencing overload.

If you can wait until October, I can offer a better slot with more space, which would allow for more cargo capacity or a reduced price.

Please let me know your thoughts.

Best regards,
Owen

---
From: ivy.chen@tradeco.com
To: owen.martin@shipbroker.com
Subject: Re: Shipping Query - Milk Powder & Grain from Sydney to Tokyo
Timestamp: 2023-06-26 09:00
Body: Dear Owen,

Thank you for the detailed information. We need to proceed with shipping the 4,000MT cargo in early July as we don't have sufficient storage capacity. Delaying the delivery could lead to product depreciation, so we'll need to stick with the original timeline.

Additionally, we will have more orders to deliver in July. Can you please assist with those as well?

Looking forward to your reply.

Best regards,
Ivy

---
From: owen.martin@shipbroker.com
To: ivy.chen@tradeco.com
Subject: Re: Shipping Query - Milk Powder & Grain from Sydney to Tokyo
Timestamp: 2023-06-26 11:30
Body: Hi Ivy,

I understand your urgency and inability to wait until October. I can propose the following solution:

- Ship 1,000MT in July
- Ship either 2,000MT or 3,000MT in August

We can accommodate 2,000MT on a 6,000dwt vessel due for September discharge, or 3,000MT on a 6,500dwt vessel also due for September discharge.

Could you specify whether you prefer to ship the milk powder or grain portion in August?

Regards,
Owen

Maria

Timestamp: 2024-05-10 14:30
Body: Ms. Maria,

20,000 bbls – May 25
30,000 bbls – May 31
140,000 bbls – June 5

Dinesh Chauhan
Singapore Representative
Sea King Shipping Co.

---
From: a.roy@seakingshipping.com
To: maria.trading@one-line.com
Subject: Re: Crude Oil Fixture Inquiry - Sakhalin to India
Timestamp: 2024-05-11 10:45
Body: Dear Ms. Maria,

We must inform you that we've received reports of significant scheduling issues at the terminal. Another carrier operating from the same terminal has been experiencing frequent cancellations and rescheduling due to force majeure. We recommend considering alternative carriers on the Japan-India route for more reliable service.

Best regards,
Aniruddha Roy
Sea King Shipping Co.

---
From: c.whipple@one-line.com
To: a.roy@seakingshipping.com
Subject: Re: Crude Oil Fixture Inquiry - Sakhalin to India
Timestamp: 2024-05-12 11:20
Body: Dear Mr. Roy,

Please be informed that we intend to cancel the contract. The shipping companies have had several strikes due to the global economic downturn.

Catherine Whipple
Manager of E-Trading
Ocean Network Express Pte. Ltd.

---
From: info@seakingshipping.com
To: c.whipple@one-line.com
Subject: Re: Crude Oil Fixture Inquiry - Sakhalin to India
Timestamp: 2024-05-12 15:45
Body: Dear Ms. Whipple,

Yours sincerely,
Sea King Shipping Co.

Timestamp: 2023-08-15 09:30

Regards,
Elaine

---
From: debatoy.lo@richpotash.com
To: elaine.chen@eleganttrading.com
Subject: Re: Potassium Hydroxide Shipment Quote Request
Timestamp: 2023-08-15 14:45
Body: Dear Elaine,

We can offer FOB, CNF, and CIF terms. Under CNF and CIF terms, we will cover port dues and insurance. For FOB terms, we require the original bill of lading to be sent to our freight forwarder before month-end.

Please let me know your preferred terms so I can provide a detailed quote.

Best regards,
Debatoy Lo
Rich Potash Trading Co., Ltd

---
From: elaine.chen@eleganttrading.com
To: debatoy.lo@richpotash.com
Subject: Re: Potassium Hydroxide Shipment Quote Request

Best regards,
Elaine

---

To: elaine.chen@eleganttrading.com
Subject: Re: Potassium Hydroxide Shipment Quote Request
Timestamp: 2023-08-16 15:30

We can arrange shipment through either Xiamen or Nansha. The goods will be ready for shipment by the end of September. Please confirm your preferred port so we can proceed with the arrangements.

Best regards,
Debatoy Lo

Mai

Mai

---

Subject: Re: Cepu Crude Oil Inquiry
Timestamp: 2024-01-15 11:30

We are looking for Crude Oil with API 26.3, sulfur content 0.35%. Could you confirm if this specification is available?

Sally

---
From: mai.nguyen@cepuoil.com
To: sally.wong@energyco.com
Subject: Re: Cepu Crude Oil Inquiry

Mai

---

Sally

Regards,
Mai

input_text:
Email 1: What's the current status of the vessel? Any news you can share? Best, Nada Email 2: Welcome to Sada, Here are the latest developments on Almarakib.

Outward bound.

Two reasons. 1. Almarakib's Pakistani captain is low on funds and is able to transport items from our port to Pakistan and earn some quick cash. He's a freelancer by nature, and is more than happy to take on whatever job comes his way as long as he gets his money upfront.

2. He is asking for $30,000 upfront. We will take out a loan for the money. We cannot afford the loan. I must sell off my share of the ship to pay it back.

I am writing this email on my phone from the bank.

I have agreed to let the bank have your share of the ship and pay off the loan.

From: donna.smith@gmail.com
To: jess.thompson@freightco.com
Subject: Book Shipment from France to NYC - Transport Options
Timestamp: 2024-02-01 09:15
Body: Hi Jess,

We'd like to discuss our next shipment of books from France to NYC. What's your transloading fee and does it apply to private parties too?

Regards,
Donna

---
From: jess.thompson@freightco.com
To: donna.smith@gmail.com
Subject: Re: Book Shipment from France to NYC - Transport Options
Timestamp: 2024-02-01 10:30
Body: Hi Donna,

The fee structure applies to all shipments. We have three options available:

Option 1:
Pickup from train station to our warehouse in Texas
Cost: $325.00 (packaging materials not included)

Option 2:
Pickup from train station to delivery in NYC
Cost: $550.00 (packaging materials not included)

Option 3:
Pickup from train station to delivery in NYC
Cost: $800.00 (packaging materials included)

Please let me know if you have any questions.

Thank you,
Jess

---
From: donna.smith@gmail.com
To: jess.thompson@freightco.com
Subject: Re: Book Shipment from France to NYC - Transport Options
Timestamp: 2024-02-01 11:45
Body: Hi Jess,

How many books are we talking about and what size are they?

Donna

---
From: jess.thompson@freightco.com
To: donna.smith@gmail.com
Subject: Re: Book Shipment from France to NYC - Transport Options
Timestamp: 2024-02-01 12:30
Body: Hi Donna,

As per the consignment agreement, the consignee is responsible for packing and documentation costs.

Regards,
Jess

---
From: donna.smith@gmail.com
To: jess.thompson@freightco.com
Subject: Re: Book Shipment from France to NYC - Transport Options
Timestamp: 2024-02-01 13:15
Body: Hi Jess,

This is regarding packing a 16th century illuminated manuscript. Do you have specific recommendations?

Donna

---
From: jess.thompson@freightco.com
To: donna.smith@gmail.com
Subject: Re: Book Shipment from France to NYC - Transport Options
Timestamp: 2024-02-01 14:00
Body: Hello Donna,

The manuscript measures 27" long, 8" wide, and 6" deep.

Sincerely,
Jess

---
From: donna.smith@gmail.com
To: jess.thompson@freightco.com
Subject: Re: Book Shipment from France to NYC - Transport Options
Timestamp: 2024-02-01 14:30
Body: Hi Jess,

Can you provide specific packing instructions?

Donna

---
From: jess.thompson@freightco.com
To: donna.smith@gmail.com
Subject: Re: Book Shipment from France to NYC - Transport Options
Timestamp: 2024-02-01 15:00
Body: Hi Donna,

As previously mentioned, the consignee will be responsible for any packaging needed.

Regards,
Jess

Kunal

---
From: chartering@shipbroker.com
To: kunal.sharma@trading.com
Subject: Re: Cargo Inquiry: Gdańsk to Tanger
Timestamp: 2024-01-15 11:45
Body: Dear Kunal,

In response to your earlier query, the freight is in the range of USD 3.50 - USD 3.75 per metric ton. It depends on the equipment chosen. We will need to know your ship and its specifications to provide a confirmed rate. Let us know and we will follow up on this further.

Best regards,
Trading Team

To: chartering@shipbroker.com

Regards,
S. M. F.

From: edward.smith@logisticspro.com
To: cory.bennett@portservices.com
Subject: Port Equipment and Service Time Inquiry
Timestamp: 2022-10-14 09:30
Body: Dear Ms. Bennett,

As a stevedore, you have access to ample cranes and loading equipment, but I understand most shipping companies prefer to hire their own personnel for discharge. We have a reputation for working fast at berthing and cargo operations, ensuring both berthing rights and successful shipments.

What's your experience with crane capacity at your ports, and can you give an estimate on service time for ships 2,600 meters and 6,500m³ cargo capacity?

Thank you,
Edward

---
From: edward.smith@logisticspro.com
To: cory.bennett@portservices.com
Subject: Re: Length and Capacity
Timestamp: 2022-10-14 10:59
Body: Dear Ms. Bennett,

Thanks for your reply. It appears neither your terminal nor mine has cranes strong enough to handle such large ships. However, we share common interests regarding Grande Comore operations. We both prioritize using reputable ports with quality equipment and speedy service while avoiding overloading.

We need to find a company that can efficiently handle the cargo, as most shipping companies prefer their own discharge personnel due to specialized requirements. Would you be interested in collaborating with our team to find a solution?

Best regards,
Edward

---
From: cory.bennett@portservices.com
To: edward.smith@logisticspro.com
Subject: Re: Length and Capacity
Timestamp: 2022-10-14 12:38
Body: Hi Edward,

What about using a multi-purpose dock, such as Port Natal? They have the most advanced docking equipment and their crews are very experienced. They are also one of the fastest ports in the world with an average unloading time of 15 minutes per ship.

Alternatively, we could consider a third-party port. I know a company called 'Aloha Stevedoring' who can handle your requirements. They have an excellent reputation with top-tier facilities.

All the best,
Cory

---
From: edward.smith@logisticspro.com
To: cory.bennett@portservices.com
Subject: Re: Third-party option
Timestamp: 2022-10-14 15:58
Body: Hi Cory,

I've been discussing this with a contact near our terminal. They've just opened a new facility in the Philippines that can handle vessels of 2,600 meters and 6,500m³ cargo capacity. They're looking to expand operations and are seeking quality partnerships.

I believe they would be interested in working with you. If you'd like to speak with them directly, please let me know.

Best regards,
Edward

---
From: cory.bennett@portservices.com
To: edward.smith@logisticspro.com
Subject: Re: Third-party option
Timestamp: 2022-10-15 09:00
Body: Hi Edward,

I'm actually in the Philippines myself, which is quite fortunate. My company can offer competitive rates and premium service for your cargo handling needs. We should discuss specific loading rates and service terms.

Looking forward to your reply.

Best regards,
Cory

Hi Terrence,                    Do you have any availability to ship 120,000 tons of bauxite from Wando to Cagliari?                    Regards,                    Fiona
Email 2:
Hi Fiona,                    Unfortunately we can not supply bauxite from Wando to Cagliari right now.                    Hope you are well!                    Terrence

#Create a Chat Bot

A bot is an automated process that performs an action for you. You can send it a message and it will respond to your message and take action on your behalf. A Chat Bot is an example of a bot.

To create a chat bot we will be making a Github Repository, to use NodeJS, this is because:

• NodeJS is one of the most popular languages used in web development today.
• NodeJS allows you to run your code server-side, which means it can process data and respond to user interactions in real time.
• NodeJS also supports JavaScript, which is a great way to get started with programming. It's an easy language to learn, and many developers already know it.
•
Email 3:
```1
Terrence 2
What are your next plans to supply bauxite from Wando to Cagliari? 3
Terrence 4
Sorry for the delay, I am traveling back from a trip to Indonesia. I will get in touch with my team and get back to you as soon as possible. 5
```

Body: Dear Maggie,

Thank you for the invitation. I hope I have understood this correctly. Daniel

To: daniel.smith@organization.com

Timestamp: 2024-01-15 15:45

Kind regards,
Walter

From: michael.smith@glassco.com
To: shipping@oceanfreight.com
Subject: Glass Shipment Chicago to Qingdao - Rate Request
Timestamp: 2024-01-15 09:30
Body: Hi,

We're planning to ship 8,000MT of glass from Chicago to Qingdao. Do you have a ready vessel, and do you offer a low discharge rate if our container is empty early?

Sincerely,
Michael

---
From: shipping@oceanfreight.com
To: michael.smith@glassco.com
Subject: Re: Glass Shipment Chicago to Qingdao - Rate Request
Timestamp: 2024-01-15 11:45
Body: Dear Michael,

We have the available space to ship the glass. The estimated costs are as follows:
- USD 6500/40HC

Regards,
Robert

---
From: david.jones@chartering.com
To: robert.smith@shipping.com
Subject: Re: Hamburg-Aarhus Fixture Rate Clarification
Timestamp: 2024-01-15 10:15
Body: Dear Robert,

I understand your question, however, while the quotation has settled at $300/MT, the vessel owner has indicated flexibility to accept $250/MT. This could present an opportunity for negotiation.

Regards,
David

---
From: robert.smith@shipping.com
To: david.jones@chartering.com
Subject: Re: Hamburg-Aarhus Fixture Rate Clarification
Timestamp: 2024-01-15 11:00
Body: Dear David,

I need to be very clear about this. The agreed rate is $300/MT all-in. If we were to negotiate a lower rate with the vessel owner, they would have no obligation to maintain the $300/MT all-in terms. My position remains firm on the original agreement.

Regards,
Robert

---
From: david.jones@chartering.com
To: robert.smith@shipping.com
Subject: Re: Hamburg-Aarhus Fixture Rate Clarification
Timestamp: 2024-01-15 11:45
Body: Dear Robert,

Please review our previous correspondence carefully. You've taken one particular stance on this matter, but there might be other approaches worth considering. I'm not making any specific proposals - I'm merely pointing out that there could be alternative solutions to explore.

Regards,
David

---
From: david.jones@chartering.com
To: robert.smith@shipping.com
Subject: Re: Hamburg-Aarhus Fixture Rate Clarification
Timestamp: 2024-01-15 13:30
Body: Hi Robert,

To be clear, I'm not proposing or assuming anything specific. I'm simply suggesting that taking such a rigid approach might be limiting from a business perspective, even if it makes sense legally.

If you'd like to discuss this further, I'm happy to schedule a call to talk through the various options.

Cheers,
David

From: alex.smith@mtlogistics.com
To: bruce.wong@shipping.com
Subject: June Shipment Questions - Dhaka to Tejing
Timestamp: 2024-06-01 09:30
Body: Hey Bruce,

Wonder if you can help with a few quick questions about our June shipment.

We got a 300MT slot from Dhaka to Tejing on 13th June. When should we arrive at Tejing port? Also, what's the daily demurrage rate there?

You rock!

Alex

---
From: bruce.wong@shipping.com
To: alex.smith@mtlogistics.com
Subject: Re: June Shipment Questions - Dhaka to Tejing
Timestamp: 2024-06-01 14:45
Body: Thanks for reaching out, I'm happy to help.

Your container should arrive on the 29th of June. The demurrage is $500 per day. As for arrival time, it depends when your truck arrives at the port and the port's efficiency. As the summer is very hot in China, the best time is around 10-11am.

Let me know if you need anything else!

Best,
Bruce

---
From: ibrahim@mtlogistics.com
To: bruce.wong@shipping.com
Subject: Shipping Options - Dhaka to China

We want to send more containers from Dhaka to China but we're not sure of the best way to do it. Can you advise on both sea and air freight options? We'd appreciate a comparison of the different methods and rates.

Best regards,

Email 1:
Dear Mr. Maier,                    Hope you’re well. Could you please tell me what the freight idea is for a cargo of palm oil from Calabar to Santa Marta, with a mid-June laycan?                    Thanks,                    Gary
Email 2:
Mr. Maier,                    Thanks for that. You should read the other section of the email.                    Gary
Email 3:
Mr. Maier,                    Thanks for the help, but that is incorrect. We are buying palm oil from Calabar not Brazil. Please read the email again.
Once again, my valued guest and the popular ‘humourous’ founder of the humour site Fuleminess  has raised a very important issue. With the growing influence of multinational business and the Internet, there is a danger of being misunderstood. Particularly when it comes to asking someone a question. With the ever growing number of emails and phonecalls being made globally every second of the day, it is important to ensure your request is heard. 

When sending an email with a question, it is also very important to include a sign off such as “Best Regards” or “Kind Regards” this is because at times a person can read the email very fast and can be assumed that the person sending the email is actually sending them
Email 4:

Dear Betsy,                    We’re expecting 6,600MT of household chemicals to leave Antwerp on Friday. If you could advise your final freight rate, we can accept it.                    Thank you,                    David
Email 2:
Hi David,                    I can confirm that the rate I quoted you earlier still stands: US$2.00 per ton FOB Antwerp, plus US$10 per package in case the packages are of different dimensions.                    Should you require additional details please let me know.                    Best wishes,                    Betsy

<Betsy to her husband, Dave>:
Here we go again! This is the third request for a quote in one day, and David seems to have given a full quote in his original email. Why do I have to explain this to him every time?
What are some reasons for replying to an email twice?
Paragraph 2 (this one) gives specific reasons in the writer’s first email. Her husband’s email serves to remind her that David is not as familiar with the company’s rates as she is.

Explain how this form of explanation might serve to establish greater rapport
Email 3:
Hi Dave,                    Why don’t you just offer the rate per ton and let David accept it or suggest alternatives?                    Do you remember in our training course, we learnt that the purpose of most email communications is not just to reply with ‘yes’ or ‘no’, but to help others make a decision?                    David’s just a little reluctant, but he will accept it and agree to it if you can help him to make a decision by making your rate specific enough.                    Best wishes,                    Betsy
<Betsy to her husband, Dave>:
Dave, I wrote you an email in the last section. Please tell me how you replied.

Regards,
Ulysses

---
From: ryan.s@shipping.com
To: ulysses.ryan@company.com
Subject: Re: Methanol Shipment Request
Timestamp: 2016-10-28 14:30
Body: Hi Ulysses,

I will handle the methanol. When the shipment arrives in Osaka, you must submit an SF-478 (Item 16) and send it to the PBO Warehouse. Then, I will make the arrangements to have it shipped from Osaka to Canada.

Regards,
Ryan

---
From: ulysses.ryan@company.com
To: ryan.s@shipping.com
Subject: Re: Methanol Shipment Request
Timestamp: 2016-10-30 10:20
Body: Ryan,

As far as I know, methanol is a hazardous material. Are there any special requirements we need to consider?

Regards,
Ulysses

---
From: ryan.s@shipping.com
To: ulysses.ryan@company.com
Subject: Re: Methanol Shipment Request
Timestamp: 2016-10-30 11:45
Body: Ulysses,

You are correct; methanol is a hazardous material and cannot be shipped commercially. Instead, I will arrange for the shipment to be carried by the Military Sealift Command, which transports military personnel and cargo.

Regards,
Ryan

Email 1:
Dear Mr. Ferris,                    My name is Samuel. I’m currently the vessel broker of a Chinese bulk carrier currently in Chittagong, Bangladesh.                    We have 3,800MT of heavy plates to load. Destination is Port Louis, Mauritius. We have been given the following port dues and fees to be deducted from the cargo:                    * General Cargo Port Dues: USD 3,256.00                    * Coast Guard Charges: USD 164.00                    * MFAF (Mauritius Free Airport Fee): USD 112.80                    * Port Corporation: USD 159.84                    * Generator Rental: USD 0.16/ Hour * 12 Hours = USD 1.92                    * Empty Tank Cleaning: USD 10.00 * 2 Tanks = USD 20.00                    Could you kindly take this into account when submitting
Email 2:
Dear Samuel,
Thank you for your email. Unfortunately it is not appropriate for you to pass charges like this on to the cargo owners without their consent. If you are able to provide evidence that this is the owners’ responsibility (e.g. a bill of lading with a clause allowing the carrier to deduct port dues from the cargo), we might be able to discuss a rate increase to cover these expenses, but if you are just making up charges to pay your agency then it is unethical and we will not pay you.
Thank you,
Alain Ferris
PS: We also need a few more details on the cargo (origin, grade, product code), which will enable us to get a more accurate quote for the freight.
PPS: The more information you are able to provide in your emails, the faster we can give you an answer, and the less likely it is that you will have

Dear Captain X,                        Thank you for your prompt reply.                        We would like to book cargo as you mentioned in your email 2.                        The information you need is as follows:                        Quantity: 30,000MT (weight)                        Type: Soybean meal                        Packed in 50kg jumbo bags                        Packed in 1,200 bags per 40'HC container                        Destination: Shantou                        Port of loading: Chongqing                        In the end of June this year, my company and a dealer made an agreement of selling and buying the above soybean meal at the agreed price of 1,300USD per MT.                        I'm wondering if I can still make the shipment at such price even now it's September.                        Thanks in advance.                        Sulek
<Email 4>:
Dear Suheki,                        I've checked with our freight
Email 4:
Dear Suheki,                        I've checked with our freight

<Email 4>:
 Dear Suheki,                        I've checked with our freight representative. I'm afraid the above rate is no longer available.                        It seems that after your July inquiry, the freight cost has been rising continuously. In September, the rate could be around 12,000USD/30,000MT. It's quite expensive compared with your original contract of 1,300USD per MT.                        I'm afraid your soybean meal could be sold at a lower price now.                        Regards,                        Captain X
Email 5:
Dear Captain X,                        That's terrible!                        It seems that we can't make it.                        At that time we agreed the contract price was only 1,300USD per MT. If we reduce the price further, we'll definitely lose some money.                        I don't know how to explain this to the client.                        I'd better tell him to take some other cargo.                        I will close this deal with the seller now.                        Thanks.                        Sulek
<Email 6>:
 Dear Suheki,                        It's a pity.                        I think that if we still insist to take the cargo, we can at least minimize the loss. We can fix the rate for the shipment.                        If we reduce the price further, we'll definitely lose some money.                        I'd better tell him to take some other cargo.                        I will close this deal with the seller now

Despite the reopening of the canal in mid-April, vessels are still facing delays as the backlog of shipping containers and other cargo continues to accumulate.

From: nada.shipping@email.com
To: sada.maritime@email.com
Subject: Vessel Almarakib Status Update Request
Timestamp: 2024-01-15 09:30
Body: What's the current status of the vessel? Any news you can share?

Best,
Nada

---
From: sada.maritime@email.com
To: nada.shipping@email.com
Subject: Re: Vessel Almarakib Status Update Request
Timestamp: 2024-01-15 11:45
Body: Dear Nada,

Here are the latest developments regarding the Almarakib:

The vessel is currently outward bound. There are two important updates:

1. The vessel's Pakistani captain is low on funds and has accepted a cargo transport job from our port to Pakistan to generate immediate income. As a freelancer, he's willing to take on this job with advance payment.

2. The captain is requesting $30,000 upfront for this voyage. We need to take out a bank loan for this amount. Unfortunately, due to our financial situation, I must sell my share of the ship to cover the loan. I'm currently at the bank finalizing arrangements where they will take your share of the vessel as collateral against the loan.

Regards,
Sada

Olivia

Email 1:
Hello Steve,                    Have a great week! My team and I are in Las Vegas this week for the NFPA Convention, but we'll be back on Monday.                    If you can please send us the routing information for your 5,500MT MGO shipment, we'll arrange for a broker to pick it up and make our arrangements to ship to Pusan.                    Thanks,                    Will
Email 2:
Hey All,                     Because I’m out of the office this week, I’m sending you some interesting projects and news to check out while I’m away!  Here are a few highlights:
* Click here to learn about the Fertilizer Institute’s new Code of Conduct, which includes nine guiding principles for good behavior, including the encouragement of a culture of safety and compliance with the law. "Anyone who works with anhydrous ammonia or other fertilizers must read this, and they must share it with their teams," says Director of Regulatory Affairs Brian Jennings.
* When a group of California manufacturers and distributors went before the California Air Resources Board (CARB) to discuss the 2013 Renewable Fuel Standard (RFS) proposed by the U.S. EPA, they did not leave empty-handed. A bill was introduced in the state legislature that would provide a tax incentive to encourage renewable fuel blending
Email 3:
It’s been busy around the warehouses. We are in the process of getting our Fall products ready. We have had some order cancellations so we will have a few spots open. We are reevaluating our shipping schedules. We are now shipping later than we did last year. It appears that the weather is not cooperating. We will keep you informed as we get better weather conditions. Some 20-inch rocks have not made it to the Southeastern states due to weather conditions and we are not sure when we will get them in.

Timestamp: 2024-01-15 09:30
Body: Dear Mr. Smith,

Your new C-Flex 1100 vessels have arrived at Ningbo Port. Would you like to charter this for our next shipment of cargo from Ningbo to Hai Phong? It's a 4,000 tons shipment of polystyrene.

When do you plan to start delivery?

---
From: alwin.smith@cflex.com
To: violet.chen@oceanfreight.com
Subject: Re: C-Flex 1100 Charter Inquiry - Ningbo to Hai Phong
Timestamp: 2024-01-15 14:45
Body: Dear Ms. Violet,

Our C-Flex 1100 vessels have indeed arrived. They can be chartered for your next shipment of cargo from Ningbo to Hai Phong. What is the shipment's ETA?

I'll need you to give us more information about the shipment, like:
* The cargo's name, weight, and volume (in cubic meters)
* Any hazardous materials on board
* Cargo description
* Cargo price
* Lashing for securing the cargo
* More requirements (like reefer containers for cargoes that need a particular temperature for preservation, etc.)

We can make a quotation when we have all the required details.

I'll be waiting for your reply.

Regards,
Alwin

Email 2:
Good morning Caroline,

I have checked with my Bitumen supplier.

### Answer options

The correct answer is C.   We need 1,300MT of bitumen


  • A.  We need 1,300MT of bitumen to Chicago                    • B.  I have checked with my supplier                    • D.  Could you name some vessels and a laycan?                    • E.  I wanted to see if we could coordinate our movements to Lyon


The best thing to do when faced with answer options is to try and make as few assumptions as possible. Although the words "we need" in the original email suggests a second person, you shouldn't immediately assume that there is more than one person at SEEDOR Company.
Try and identify the people who are talking about the 1,300MT.
The correct answer is "we".  So, this 1

Dear Sven,                    Please confirm the price of 12,000MT of chemicals.                    Kind regards,                    Jake

In my previous post I introduced how the transformer can be used to set up a casual model using a combination of supervised and unsupervised learning. I wanted to apply this methodology to email correspondence analysis but had no good starting points to learn from. So, I decided to have a go at using a large email data set to set up an email correspondence model. In this post, I’ll describe my method and then evaluate it.
## Previous Work
I found two other email correspondence analyses:
Both papers claimed to have a small error rate (below 5%) but no error rate figures were provided. Their methods included analyzing only the destination of emails and ignoring the subjects and whether the email was replied to or not.
## Data
