Sincerely,
Jeremy

---
From: susan.miller@logistics.com
To: jeremy.smith@woodtrade.com
Subject: Re: Wood Panel Transport Inquiry - Bordeaux to Bilbao
Timestamp: 2024-02-01 11:15
Body: Dear Jeremy,

Thanks for your email about the transport of wood panels from Bordeaux to Bilbao. What is the weight of the panels? If they are 1.6 cubic meters (a typical wood pallet size) with a panel thickness of about 2.5cm, that's approximately 1,000kg/m³ with a density of 1.7. Do you have any other measurements?

Regards,
Susan

---
From: jeremy.smith@woodtrade.com
To: susan.miller@logistics.com
Subject: Re: Wood Panel Transport Inquiry - Bordeaux to Bilbao
Timestamp: 2024-02-01 13:45
Body: Hi Susan,

Yes, all panels are 1.6 cubic meters and 2.5cm thick, so I can use your equation to find the weight (1,000kg/m³ * 1.6 cubic meters = 1,600kg).

How about this deal? How many cubic meters can your truck transport from Bordeaux to Bilbao? How many total trips will the vehicle make? What is the total cost for transport?

Thanks!
Jeremy

---
From: susan.miller@logistics.com
To: jeremy.smith@woodtrade.com
Subject: Re: Wood Panel Transport Inquiry - Bordeaux to Bilbao
Timestamp: 2024-02-01 15:20
Body: Dear Jeremy,

Thanks for your email. Our truck can transport 24 cubic meters at a time from Bordeaux to Bilbao. The total cost would be 10,000 euros. We will also cover all of your customs costs and administrative fees in the EU and at the destination.

Regards,
Susan

---

Jeremy

Susan

Body: Hi David,

From: betsy.wilson@freight.com
To: dave.wilson@freight.com
Subject: Re: Quote Response Strategy
Timestamp: 2024-02-01 10:45
Body: Hi Dave,

Why don't you just offer the rate per ton and let David accept it or suggest alternatives?

Do you remember in our training course, we learnt that the purpose of most email communications is not just to reply with 'yes' or 'no', but to help others make a decision?

David's just a little reluctant, but he will accept it and agree to it if you can help him to make a decision by making your rate specific enough.

Best wishes,
Betsy

Dear Messrs Rettig and Nogales,                    I hear that you are in talks to form a new entity, can you confirm this?                    It will be good news for the industry if you can demonstrate a joint offer that provides real added value. Email 2:

From: sid.trader@mail.com
To: recipient@company.com
Subject: Petroleum Coke Shipment Query - Cape Town
Timestamp: 2024-01-15 09:30
Body: Hello my old friend,

A little birdie tells me you have an urgent need to get 3,000MT of petroleum coke into Cape Town. You don't have space on the F/A ABLYN which is at Latakia? Are you going to wait for her next stop, after a quick turn around in Sudan? Or are you desperate?

Yours,
Sid

---
From: sid.trader@mail.com
To: recipient@company.com
Subject: Re: Petroleum Coke Shipment Query - Cape Town
Timestamp: 2024-01-15 14:45
Body: Hi again,

Here is the story. I can make you an offer you can't refuse. Remember when I mentioned a quick turn-around in Sudan? Well, the job is not for me. It's for my cousin. He has taken over my business. He is not as nice as me. Don't worry, I can get your oil to South Africa.

Yours,
Sid

---
From: sid.trader@mail.com
To: recipient@company.com
Subject: Re: Petroleum Coke Shipment Query - Cape Town
Timestamp: 2024-01-16 10:15
Body: Salam Aliki,

Remember me? I was one of those sailors you knew in Dubai. I am in Cape Town now. I have a good deal for you.

Three thousand metric tons of petroleum coke, sapphire black, stored in an oil tanker on the Black Sea.
First offer: $500,000
Second offer: $150,000 per metric ton for the whole load.

Salam,
Sid

---
From: sid.trader@mail.com
To: recipient@company.com
Subject: Re: Petroleum Coke Shipment Query - Cape Town
Timestamp: 2024-01-17 08:20
Body: Salam,

Let me know if you want the deal. The seller is asking for 150,000 dollars per metric ton. The deal will be closed when you sign the contracts. An independent bank will transfer the funds after the transaction.

Salam,
Sid

---
From: sid.trader@mail.com
To: recipient@company.com
Subject: Re: Petroleum Coke Shipment Query - Cape Town
Timestamp: 2024-01-18 11:30
Body: Salam,

The seller is still waiting. I told you not to wait too long to reply to this offer. If you don't, someone else will. Who knows where this oil will end up?

Salam,
Sid

input_text:
Email 1:
Hi Basil,                    Could you handle 5,400MT of vegetable oil from Aqaba to Mombasa, with full documentation? And how much is your storage fee?                    Regards,                    Sina
Email 2:
From: _Sina?_
To: _Ivan?_
Sent: _Thursday, August 19, 2010 9:17:08 AM_
Subject: RE: Storage

> How much is your storage fee? 


   _> And who will deliver this quantity to our factory?_ 

So, there was this corporation who asked about our storage and delivery cost. First question they asked was about storage cost. I made sure to talk about all different prices based on different quantities and then I explained the storage conditions. I never mentioned that in my price I included free delivery to the factory, in my opinion it is better to ask all questions before talking about details. You do not know what questions they can ask.

When I received the email below, I was a bit shocked about the question. However I managed to answer it quickly as follows:

Sina

From:
Email 3:
> _We can handle your storage in Mombasa. The price is 1.2$/MT on 1 month with total quantity of 5,400MTs. We can deliver the cargo by truck directly to your factory. But the price depends on the distance._ 


> _For example, from Mombasa port to Machakos it is 70 Km. The price is 40/MT. From Mombasa to Athi river it is 50KM. The price is 30/MT._


> _Regards, Basil_ 


Dear Sina, Thank you for your email. We can handle your storage in Mombasa. The price is 1.2$/MT on 1 month with total quantity of 5,400MTs. We can deliver the cargo by truck directly to your factory. But the price depends on the distance. For

Liam

Liam

To: mendoza.p@shipping.es
Subject: Cargo Inquiry Barcelona-Puerto Madryn
Timestamp: 2024-03-10 09:15
Body: Hello Ms. Mendoza,

We have a cargo of 2,200MT which we are hoping to load to a feeder vessel on the 15th, departing Barcelona on the 17th. The discharge is at Puerto Madryn in Argentina.

Please confirm your earliest loading date and advise on transit times.

Kind regards,
Anne Marie

---
From: mendoza.p@shipping.es
To: anne.marie@chartering.com
Subject: Re: Cargo Inquiry Barcelona-Puerto Madryn
Timestamp: 2024-03-10 14:30
Body: Hi Anne Marie,

The cargo you have quoted will fit comfortably on MV ACATENANGO.

This ship will load in Aviles, Spain on the 13th March and sail the following day to Madryn, Argentina.

On arrival in Madryn, the cargo will discharge in two weeks time, approximately on the 26th March. This will give you approximately two weeks transit time from Spain to Madryn.

I will send you the following details:
- Laycan: 13th March
- Prelim D/D
- Report of Findings: 12th March
- First Week: 15th-22nd March
- Second Week: 22nd-29th March
- D/D (SPB form)
- Expected discharge: 26th March
- Invoice: 19th March

Please confirm the delivery to Madryn, Argentina.

Best regards

---
From: operations@shipping.es
To: anne.marie@chartering.com
Subject: Milestones - MV ACATENANGO
Timestamp: 2024-03-11 10:00
Body: Milestones to be completed between 14.03 and 20.03:

- 14.03: MM automatically notifies the principals the completion of the "Report of Findings"
- 18.03: MM automatically notifies the vessel owner of the completion of the preliminary D/D
- 18.03: Vessel owner should approve the D/D within 24 hours
- 18.03: Vessel owner is required to download the preliminary D/D and secure the vessel
- 20.03: The first week of the pre-laycan D/D expires

---
From: operations@shipping.es
To: anne.marie@chartering.com
Subject: Contract Confirmation - MV ACATENANGO
Timestamp: 2024-03-11 15:45
Body: Dear Vessel Owner and Vessel Manager,

We are pleased to announce that we have agreed to the following contract regarding the cargo booking you made for shipment to Argentina.

Arrangements have already been made with your agent Mr. McCarthy in Barcelona, Spain and our MD to make all the required arrangements.

Vessel details for MV ACATENANGO will be handled by:

Chibest Vessels (M.V) Inc
Attention: Ms. Pia Arroyo
8 Ellery Lane
Bromley Hill Industrial Estate
Kent, BR1 4RQ
United Kingdom

Best regards

Yanyan

---
From: amr.elgarhy@globmarine.com
To: yanyan.liu@tradeco.com
Subject: Re: Vessel Inquiry: Fujairah to Dar es Salaam
Timestamp: 2024-02-01 14:30
Body: Dear Yanyan,

Thank you for your inquiry. Following our previous communications regarding the vessel S & P, we regret to inform you that there is an issue with the vessel's P&I coverage. The owner does not provide the Vessel's P&I insurance, which would need to be covered by the charterer.

Amr El-Garhy
Sales Department
Globmarine Chartering Limited
Dubai, UAE

Email 1:
The total capacity required is 36,000 metric tonnes of glycol from Mexico to Luanda in Angola.                    Any suitable vessels?                    Best regards,                    your name
Email 2:
Yesterday you were looking for suitable vessels for 36,000 metric tonnes of glycol from Mexico to Luanda in Angola.                    I have a ship available.           36,000 MT = 36,000 ton x 1,000 kg/ton = 36,000,000 kg = 3,600 m3 at a density of 1 ton/m3                    The ship can carry 5,500,000 litres.                    5,500,000 litres x 1 m3/1,000 litres = 5,500 m3                    Let me know if this is suitable.                    The shipment costs US$100,000 (can be deducted from the commission that you pay to me)                   36,000 MT = 36,000 ton x 1,000 kg/ton = 36,000,000 kg = 3,600 m3
Email 3:
The price per litre is $10, so 5,500 m3 of ethanol is worth US$55,000.
The net profit for the shippers is US$55,000 - US$100,000 = US$55,000.
Let me know how you feel about this arrangement. 
Best regards,
Email 4:
If this offer from the shippers is accepted, I will issue a commission invoice to you (as agent) as follows:
100% net profit is $55,000
Commission is 5% of net profit is $2,750
The balance of $52,250 is to be deposited by you (the client) in my bank account and you will then get the balance of $100,000 less commission.
Please send a signed copy of the attached contract.  I will provide a copy for you to sign.
If you have any queries about this arrangement, please get back to me.
Email 5:
Thank you.  The contract has been signed and returned.
Please open an account for me (in the same bank as the shippers), and I will be happy to deposit the balance of $52,250 and receive the commission of $2,750.
Please send me the bank account details and I will open an account immediately.
Best regards,                    

<Email 6>:
Thank you. The bank details have been provided.
Please get back to me with the balance in your account.
Thank you. 


<Email 7>:

From: samuel.chen@vesselbroker.com
To: alain.ferris@maritime-trade.com
Subject: Port Charges Query - Heavy Plates Shipment to Port Louis
Timestamp: 2024-02-15 09:30
Body: Dear Mr. Ferris,

My name is Samuel. I'm currently the vessel broker of a Chinese bulk carrier currently in Chittagong, Bangladesh.

We have 3,800MT of heavy plates to load. Destination is Port Louis, Mauritius. We have been given the following port dues and fees to be deducted from the cargo:

* General Cargo Port Dues: USD 3,256.00
* Coast Guard Charges: USD 164.00
* MFAF (Mauritius Free Airport Fee): USD 112.80
* Port Corporation: USD 159.84
* Generator Rental: USD 0.16/Hour * 12 Hours = USD 1.92
* Empty Tank Cleaning: USD 10.00 * 2 Tanks = USD 20.00

Could you kindly take this into account when submitting your freight quote?

Best regards,
Samuel

---
From: alain.ferris@maritime-trade.com
To: samuel.chen@vesselbroker.com
Subject: Re: Port Charges Query - Heavy Plates Shipment to Port Louis
Timestamp: 2024-02-15 14:45
Body: Dear Samuel,

Thank you for your email. Unfortunately, it is not appropriate for you to pass charges like this on to the cargo owners without their consent. If you are able to provide evidence that this is the owners' responsibility (e.g. a bill of lading with a clause allowing the carrier to deduct port dues from the cargo), we might be able to discuss a rate increase to cover these expenses, but if you are just making up charges to pay your agency then it is unethical and we will not pay you.

We also need a few more details on the cargo (origin, grade, product code), which will enable us to get a more accurate quote for the freight.

The more information you are able to provide in your emails, the faster we can give you an answer.

Thank you,
Alain Ferris

input_text:
Email 1:
Good Morning,                    We have a load of 150k MT of crude oil coming out of Vung Tau on 22nd September. The cargo should be shipped in Hapag Lloyd vessel, perhaps with the product name “XONE”.                    Can you advise us if your vessel is available for this cargo?                    We’re grateful for your help.                    Best regards,                    Natalie                    [Your address]
Email 2:
Dear [Your name],                    Our cargo of crude oil “XONE” will come out of Vung Tau in Vietnam on the 20th of September on board the Hapag Lloyd vessel “Venezuela”.                    How can we send you this cargo?                    We are looking forward to hearing from you.                    Best regards,                    [Your name]                    [Your address]

I would like to share with you a couple of situations I have recently experienced regarding sales. The main factor here is that every port of origin in this region has its own cargo’s name that differs from one port to another. Let me give you an example. Vung Tau’s oil is usually known as “XONE”, for example. If the cargo’s origin was not Vung Tau, it would be known as something different. In the first email, the seller is probably from Vung Tau, the port
Email 3:
<3>
Thanks for your email.                    We have an available vessel. Could you please share the port of origin?                    Thanks.                    Best regards,                    [Your name]                    [Your address]

so he doesn’t want to use the common port of origin name, but he wants to use the name of the port where his product originates from.

We have, however, to be cautious when receiving information from an agent, because often it is not completely correct. If the agent wants to sell his cargo by using an incorrect cargo name, it is much easier for him to trick the buyer by giving a name that has a higher profit for him, or a name that is more familiar for the potential buyer. This issue is something that we have to be aware of. We have to make sure that the cargo is what we think it is, and if we’re sure that we know the exact

For reference, we have recorded the following details:

Date of Arrival: 8th February 2015
Position of Vessel: Offshore of Bandar Mahshahr, awaiting tug
Type of Vessel: 105,000 DWT Crude Oil Tanker
Draft of Vessel: 15.50 meters

Best regards

input_text:
Email 1:
We need to ship 4,000MT of HFO from Fujairah to Dar es Salaam. Are you in the market, and are these port dues included in your rate?                    Best regards,                    Donald
Email 2:
Fujairah/Dar es Salaam. We are ready to pay $1,900/MT CIF Dar es Salaam.                     Best regards,                     Donald
Email 3:
We need to ship 4,000MT of HFO from Fujairah to Dar es Salaam. Are you in the market, and are these port dues included in your rate?                     Best regards,                     Donald


They get a reply to only the last email. There are reasons why they could be having difficulty in getting through to their target. This happens frequently when it comes to end-user targets in emerging markets.
I always leave two days in my inbox to send another follow up email after the first one is sent and then at the end of the day send another one. This seems to work better than the more traditional 3-day/3-email rule.

While we see high open rates, it’s possible that the real target isn’t looking for the product at this time and may not have read the email. You don’t really know for sure unless you get a reply from the target

An HTML attachment was scrubbed...
URL: https://lists.tux.org/pipermail/cargo-cptn-discuss/attachments/20190522/3d4f226c/attachment-0002.html

<Email 4>:
 On Mon, May 20, 2019 at 05:54 PM,  wrote:

* Why the captain and other crew leave the bridge, walk away from the wheel, and forget where the wheel is? Is this typical, or is it just human nature?

 It is not typical. Any crew that is leaving the bridge for more than a few minutes will usually assign a watchkeeper and/or specify exactly where the wheel is. If the owner insists on an automatic pilot watchkeeper, it is up to the captain to comply. But that would not be my recommendation.

* If the vessel is in or near a harbor or channel where there are many vessels and navigating is a challenge, why do the ships leave the bridge and let the ship just drift out of control? Would not knowing exactly where the wheel is be a problem? I am talking about not having a person at the helm ready
Email 5:
Mr. McDonough,

I think your data show that the cost of maritime transportation has dropped significantly over the past three years, although the bunker prices have climbed.

Could you please compare two particular time periods? Thanks.

Best Regards,

Heather

From: angela.smith@brokerfirm.com
To: felicia.jones@company.com
Subject: Change in Account Management
Timestamp: 2024-01-15 14:30
Body: Dear Felicia,

Please note that Dr. Alexander will be leaving our brokering firm at the end of the month. I will be taking over your account and would be happy to schedule a meeting to discuss ongoing matters.

Would you have any availability early next week?

Many thanks in advance and best regards,
Angela

---
From: felicia.jones@company.com
To: angela.smith@brokerfirm.com
Subject: Re: Change in Account Management
Timestamp: 2024-01-15 15:45
Body: Hi Angela,

Thanks for your quick reply. We actually just recently set up a meeting with Patrick Winkelmayer. If I remember correctly, he's the one who showed strong interest in our portfolio.

I'm keen to understand his plans for future collaboration. I'm including his recent email correspondence below for your reference.

Best regards,
Felicia

---
From: felicia.jones@company.com
To: patrick.winkelmayer@brokerfirm.com
Subject: Re: Spangler Proposal Review
Timestamp: 2024-01-14 10:15
Body: Dear Patrick,

I received the proposal from Paul Spangler's firm. As discussed, please find my comments below:

1) We would like to reduce the number of projects for which we plan to broker deals with you. This isn't due to concerns about your capabilities, but rather to start with a focused approach. The deal with the American electronics firm is our first priority.

2) Regarding the electronics deal, please consider accelerating the timeline. We've noticed American firms are increasingly looking to work with British firms to access their competitive tax rates. An earlier timeline would make us more attractive.

3) Regarding your quoted rate for the electronics firm deal...

---
From: felicia.jones@company.com
To: patrick.winkelmayer@brokerfirm.com
Subject: Termination of Electronics Firm Deal
Timestamp: 2024-01-16 09:00
Body: Dear Patrick,

I regret to inform you that we will not be proceeding with the electronics firm deal. Your negotiation approach is pushing the company beyond their current comfort zone and capabilities.

It was a pleasure working with you.

Sincerely,
Felicia

From: john.paul@sigisanaa.com
To: roger.brown@brownshipping.com
Subject: Freight Quote Request - Bauxite from Port Beni
Timestamp: 2006-03-20 09:15
Body: Good morning Mr. Brown,

We have a load of Bauxite coming out of Port Beni, Peru, approx. 40,000MT, FOB. Please advise your best freight estimate.

Sincerely,
John Paul

---
From: roger.brown@brownshipping.com
To: john.paul@sigisanaa.com
Subject: Re: Freight Quote Request - Bauxite from Port Beni
Timestamp: 2006-03-20 10:30
Body: Hi John,

I'm assuming you're with Sigi Sanaa Shipping Corp. If that is correct, your freight rates are as follows:

HK: USD2.20/MT
TZ: USD3.40/MT
SK: USD1.10/MT
CW: USD2.00/MT
RH: USD0.90/MT
JO: USD1.90/MT

As per Custom clearance, cargo will be delivered at sidong railway/terminal. Freight, customs and railway charges depending on load and transportation will be included at spot rate - subject to railway cooperation and availability of wagons.

This is a FREIGHT estimate. Let me know if you want an FOB-CIF estimate instead.

Regards,
Roger Brown

---
From: john.paul@sigisanaa.com
To: roger.brown@brownshipping.com
Subject: Re: Freight Quote Request - Bauxite from Port Beni

Also, we have another similar shipment at the same time with the same rate to FRSA, Hook with FOB of May 29th 2006. Please advise.

Sincerely,
John Paul

---

Roger Brown

From: al.broker@seaship.com
To: zara.chen@gmail.com
Subject: Corn Starch Shipment Quote - Bangkok to Haiphong
Timestamp: 2024-02-01 09:30
Body: Dear Zara,

Glad to provide you with a quote for your bulk corn starch shipment from Bangkok to Haiphong.

Seafreight CFR Haiphong: $1081.25 /MT
Demurrage rate: $150.00 /day

Can you let me know your exact size, quality, ETA, and type of packaging?

Looking forward to working with you,
Al

---
From: zara.chen@gmail.com
To: al.broker@seaship.com
Subject: Re: Corn Starch Shipment Quote - Bangkok to Haiphong
Timestamp: 2024-02-01 14:15
Body: Dear Al,

Thank you for the quote. Following my mother's recent passing, I would like to make an advance payment of $15,000 for this shipment. My mother was a philanthropist, and this transaction would honor her memory.

Please provide your bank details for the transfer.

Best regards,
Zara

---
From: al.broker@seaship.com
To: zara.chen@gmail.com
Subject: Re: Corn Starch Shipment Quote - Bangkok to Haiphong
Timestamp: 2024-02-02 10:00
Body: Dear Zara,

What a thoughtful and kind person you are. I appreciate your desire to honor your mother's memory, and I admire her values.

Your advance payment is much appreciated, and I will use it to pay for the transportation costs. Please be assured that your shipment will be handled with utmost care and delivered promptly and safely.

If you have any questions or concerns, feel free to reach out to me. Looking forward to a long-lasting and fruitful business relationship with you.

Best regards,
Al

---
From: zara.chen@gmail.com
To: al.broker@seaship.com
Subject: Change of Delivery Point - Bangkok to HCMC
Timestamp: 2024-02-03 11:30
Body: Dear Al,

I need to change the delivery point from Haiphong to Ho Chi Minh City (HCMC). I have received a new booking number which I will forward separately.

Best regards,
Zara

---
From: al.broker@seaship.com
To: zara.chen@gmail.com
Subject: Re: Change of Delivery Point - Bangkok to HCMC
Timestamp: 2024-02-03 15:45
Body: Dear Zara,

We're having a hard time switching the delivery point. I've talked to the shipping line and their only solution is to send the shipment back to Bangkok so it can be shipped to the correct location. Unfortunately, the cost of this is very high, and I don't think it's a viable option for you.

Best regards,
Al

---
From: al.broker@seaship.com
To: zara.chen@gmail.com
Subject: Re: Change of Delivery Point - Bangkok to HCMC
Timestamp: 2024-02-04 09:15
Body: Dear Zara,

I've talked to the shipping line again, and they have agreed to make the necessary changes to the shipment so it can be delivered to Ho Chi Minh City instead of Haiphong. However, the cost of this change will be substantial.

Best regards,
Al

Email 1:
<WRITE EMAIL C>                    Now email yourself the three emails and compare them. How are they the same? How are they different? Why does it matter?
                                    Write a draft of a short letter you would send to an expert in the field of your career interest. The letter should explain your interest and describe your academic background and experience. Introduce an area of inquiry about the field in which you are interested, and end with a request to speak with this expert about career possibilities in the field. Draft this letter to this week’s guest speaker, Dr.
Email 2:
Dear <NAME>,
I am writing to you because I am highly interested in computer engineering and in designing advanced technology, and I want to know what steps I can take to reach my goal. I want to know what work and learning opportunities are available in computer engineering. I have found out a lot about computer engineering and I have done the research. I want to know what path I need to take to become successful in computer engineering. I have taken a number of classes and learned about the core material that I need for computer engineering.
I want to have more information about computer engineering and what experiences you had in this field. I want to know what steps you took to get to where you are now, and what I need to do to get there. I have done some research, but I do not know what my next step is.
I want to know what classes I should take and what organizations
Email 3:
Dear <NAME>,
My name is <NAME>. I would like to write to you for a few questions that have been bugging me. I have heard of many stories about how to get into a career path I am interested in, and I am wondering which one to follow. I’m interested in psychology as a career and have tried to look into what steps I need to take to get where I want to be.
I would like to know what steps I should take to become successful in psychology. I know that I need to major in psychology and complete my requirements. I also know that there are many other requirements to become successful, like doing internships and taking many more classes. I want to know what your experience was, and what I need to do to get where you are now.
Thank you for your time,

input_text:
Email 1:
Hey Jake,                    Let’s say we’re to pick up 20,000MT from Sumatra to Suez around August. How about we have a four-week laycan, starting 1st August?                    Any ideas about freight and duration of voyage?                    Regards,                    Stanley
Email 2:
Dear Mr Steffes,                      Our Hamburg South America Line was approached by your agents E  \& T             Group to transport iron ore from Indonesia to South America.                 You are hereby invited to send your offers for the transport of 20,000mt of iron ore, with a laycan from 1st August to the beginning of September.                 The main characteristics are as follows:                      - the load will be from the Sumatra region                      - the cargo will be iron ore of Fe 62%                      - the discharge port is to be selected and confirmed by the buyer                 Please send all offers on a non-negotiable basis (ex works) in USD based on the FOB Hamburg price of iron ore (ie, US$78/mt).                 For the selected shipping line, please send the freight and sailing costs in USD (ex works).                 In addition to the above
Email 3:
Sorry for the delay in getting back to you. We’ve been dealing with an issue concerning the vessels’ bills of lading. 
I understand your cargo will be subject to an inspection at the port of discharge.  Since this is out of our control, you should contact your 
broker or agent to determine the inspection’s requirements, including duration and time of day for the inspection.  The bill of lading, while you 
were out, contained a statement stating we were responsible for the inspection's duration.  We subsequently deleted that paragraph.
We understand your client will be taking full responsibility for their merchandise at the port of discharge. Therefore, they should assume responsibility 
for ensuring that their merchandise clears customs.  We understand that you are working with our agent at the port of discharge to file the necessary documents 
to clear the cargo.  However, if you encounter any problems, please feel
Email 4:
I hope you’re well.
                 The client has changed the discharge port from Hamburg to Antwerp, Belgium.  Unfortunately, we had to sign a bill of lading without 
notifying you because the cargo was already on board and sailing.  We will now follow your advice and contact our agent at the port of 
discharge to make sure all of the necessary documents are filed in order to clear the cargo.
                 As requested, I will also forward a copy of the bill of lading to you and hope to have a firm confirmation of the inspection schedule 
for the cargo.
                 Regards,
Email 5:
Hi Stanley,
                 We have received confirmation from our agent in Antwerp that the necessary documents have been filed and the 
cargo is cleared.
                 The inspection should start tomorrow morning, beginning at 9 am.
                 I will forward a copy of the bill of lading to you as soon as possible.
                 Regards,
    6)

Subject: Bitumen Shipment to Maputo - Transport Inquiry
Timestamp: 2024-02-01 09:30
Body: Dear Sir,

We have 6,000MT of bitumen from IADC to be delivered to Maputo. Could you share your available windows and dispatch incentives?

Best regards,
Harry

---
From: jelena.kovac@oilservices.com
To: harry.smith@trading.com
Subject: Re: Bitumen Shipment to Maputo - Transport Inquiry
Timestamp: 2024-02-01 11:45
Body: Dear Harry,

I'm afraid our operations are limited to a small network of petroleum engineers within our company hierarchy. Our website describes our business development activities, and since we're not agents of any refineries, our trucks are not available to carry goods for other refineries.

Thank you for your understanding.

Regards,
Jelena

---
From: harry.smith@trading.com
To: jelena.kovac@oilservices.com
Subject: Re: Bitumen Shipment to Maputo - Transport Inquiry
Timestamp: 2024-02-01 14:20
Body: Dear Jelena,

Good afternoon, I am sorry if our letter was misunderstood. We have no other refinery involved in delivering the bitumen to Maputo - the deal is between IADC and us. The CIF price offered is specifically for Maputo.

Sincerely,
Harry

---
From: jelena.kovac@oilservices.com
To: harry.smith@trading.com
Subject: Re: Bitumen Shipment to Maputo - Transport Inquiry
Timestamp: 2024-02-01 16:15
Body: Dear Sir,

Greetings. We refer to the emails you have sent and our last one. For clarification, please be advised that we are not a refinery, we are an Oil Services Company and the trucks belong to us. We have recently made a contract with the IADC refinery to ship 6,000MT of bitumen to Maputo and we are asking if you have some interested buyers in this location.

Regards,
Jelena

From: jane.smith@trading.com
To: broker@shipping.com
Subject: Freight Estimate Request - Ethanol Maceió/Houston
Timestamp: 2023-08-15 09:30
Body: Good morning,

Could you provide a freight estimate for 3,900MT of ethanol from Maceió to Houston in late August? Also, is laytime counted on arrival or upon NOR?

Thanks for your help,
Jane

---
From: broker@shipping.com
To: jane.smith@trading.com
Subject: Re: Freight Estimate Request - Ethanol Maceió/Houston
Timestamp: 2023-08-15 10:45
Body: Hi Jane,

Are you sure of your MT readings? These seem to be off by a lot. It will probably be several months until the ethanol has finished being stored in the tanks. Could you please verify the quantities and let me know?

Thanks,
Zoe

---
From: jane.smith@trading.com
To: broker@shipping.com
Subject: Re: Freight Estimate Request - Ethanol Maceió/Houston
Timestamp: 2023-08-15 11:30
Body: Hi Zoe,

I just looked up prices for ethanol in Houston from Singapore, Brazil, and Egypt. They are all pretty much the same - only a 3 USD difference. In July, Brazil was cheaper, but now in August, Egypt is slightly cheaper, though that could change quickly.

I'm going to go with the MT readings as shown and work with a delivered price of 1 USD from Maceió. I need this information to estimate the gas requirements for profitability.

Thank you for all your help. You are a great addition to the company.

---
From: aimee.jones@trading.com
To: broker@shipping.com
Subject: New Freight Estimate Request - Maceió/Houston
Timestamp: 2023-08-15 14:15
Body: Hi Zoe,

Could you estimate freight for 2,500MT from Maceió to Houston in late June/early July? Also, would you be willing to cover the 10% buyer's commission?

Best,
Aimee

input_text:
Email 1:
Good evening Mr. Menéndez,                    We’ll need a calculation for 3,000MT of diesel from Rotterdam to the 13 docks at Aarhus. Does the 24/7 service you provide include all seasonal holidays?                    Kind regards,                    Abbie
Email 2:
Thanks, Abbie,        Here are some details.        Please do your calculations assuming a spread of 5 to 15 days for loading. If you use 10 days, please note that it will make your calculation more conservative.        These are some other terms you need to consider:        – guaranteed loading window 5 days (as a rule, we do 10% out of this time if the barge is ready at the quay or 10% per day extra from our client’s terminal if the barge is not ready at the quay).        – rotation time: 24h maximum        – unloading time: 24h maximum        – total transit time: 48h        – all statutory holidays are considered normal workdays for shippers.        – routing: Oslo-Fredericia-Middelfart-Harsholm-Portland-Jakobsen        –

Seth

input_text:
Email 1:
Hello Sir,                    Do you think a big container ship will be built in China? Is it better to own a small ship or to own an interest in a large container ship?                    Thank you,                    Andre
Email 2:
Dear Sir,
Since my last letter, I have been reading a
book on Containership Business and i have a
lot of ideas.
Here is one of them. Will a large container
ship be built in China? Is it a good
investment to own a small container ship or
to own an interest in a large ship? I
believe that the container shipping industry
will get better and better. At this time, the
shipping market is very strong.
Here is the conclusion:
It is better to own a small container ship
than to own an interest in a large container
ship. We should stick to our belief.
Thank you,
Andre
Email 3:
Dear Sir,
Since my last letter, I have been reading a
book on the Container Business and
understanding the idea. After a lot of
thinking, I found a logical solution.
It is better to own a small container ship
than to own an interest in a large container
ship. That is the truth. We can be more
stable in the long run.
Please do not forget what I have said. I am
waiting for your reply.
Thank you,
Andre

From: adam.smith@company.com
To: helberg.shipping@sealand.com
Subject: Rate Request - Chemical Shipment Westport to Long Beach
Timestamp: 2024-02-20 09:15
Body: Ms. Helberg,

We've got a 5,000MT of chemicals requiring transport from Westport, LA to Long Beach, CA. Could you please provide your rate quote for this shipment? Also, could you advise on any current dock congestion situations at Long Beach?

Thank you,
Adam

---
From: helberg.shipping@sealand.com
To: adam.smith@company.com
Subject: RE: Rate Request - Chemical Shipment Westport to Long Beach
Timestamp: 2024-02-20 11:30
Body: Hi Adam,

Good day! Thank you for your inquiry. I must inform you that we currently don't have local agents at Westport. We only operate shipments from LA, Long Beach, or Hueneme ports.

This means we cannot arrange local delivery pickups or handle port activities at Westport. These would need to be arranged by the shipment owner or a third-party company.

For reference, our current rates for similar shipments from our operating ports to Long Beach are:
- Ocean Freight: USD 1,862
- Port Charges: USD 1,858

We're currently offering a 6% discount on our services, which would result in savings of approximately USD 362.

Please let me know if you would like to discuss alternative arrangements through our operating ports.

Best regards,
Ms. Helberg

Email 2:
David,                         We need to add the price of bunker to shipowners is more expensive than selling bunker, since our agent will pay for all bunker in VETSA trades.                    Also please consider the fact that our ship is selling product from Daesan to India before load jet to Daesan.                    So it will be 16.74 US/MT with bunker at VETSA trades.                    Hope this helps.                    Let me know what you think.                    Eddie
                    
<Email 3>:                      If I understand you correctly you need to make an estimate at load (in this case Daesan) about how much bunker will be consumed until the vessel arrives in discharge port. However, in reality most of the bunker will be consumed when the vessel travels from load to discharge port and you should pay to us the bunker consumed only from discharge port to load. From: ian.smith@tradingco.com
To: sam.wilson@maritimebrokers.com
Subject: Cotton Shipment - Panama Canal Toll Query
Timestamp: 2024-01-15 09:23
Body: Hey Sam,

We are interested in the second shipment of cotton under 50-ton container in direct sail from Santa Cruz to Newark. Will the new Charter Party apply the New Panama Canal toll?

Thanks,
Ian

---
From: sam.wilson@maritimebrokers.com
To: ian.smith@tradingco.com
Subject: Re: Cotton Shipment - Panama Canal Toll Query
Timestamp: 2024-01-15 10:45
Body: Hi Ian,

Where can I find this 'new Charter Party' you mention? I have the latest canal treaty with me, but it says nothing about a new C/P. Can you please clarify?

Regards,
Sam

---
From: ian.smith@tradingco.com
To: sam.wilson@maritimebrokers.com
Subject: Re: Cotton Shipment - Panama Canal Toll Query
Timestamp: 2024-01-15 11:30
Body: Sam,

Please refer to the canal toll agreement here:
http://www.panamaxmaritime.com/AG/Panama%20Canal%20Tolls%20Agreement.pdf

The addendum discusses toll rates for container vessels. As per the Neutrality Treaty, the Panama Canal should operate equitably for all merchant vessels. The tolls should be consistent with established rates.

Best,
Ian

---
From: sam.wilson@maritimebrokers.com
To: ian.smith@tradingco.com
Subject: Re: Cotton Shipment - Panama Canal Toll Query
Timestamp: 2024-01-15 12:15
Body: Ian,

I suspect we will need to hire a cargo lawyer. We should challenge this on grounds of discrimination. We could seek a legal opinion from the Secretary of State for Transport, or alternatively engage a private firm to challenge the canal authorities directly.

At minimum, we need clarification on their 'adjusted and equitable tolls' arrangement. However, I should mention that our principals are generally reluctant to engage in legal proceedings.

Regards,
Sam

Subject: Transport Query - Used Milkers Lydenburg to Gaborone
Timestamp: 2016-07-20 09:00
Body: Hey Jane,

Interested in taking on a cargo of used milkers. If we could move the milkers from Lydenburg, RSA to Gaborone, Botswana, can you send us the details for loading and unloading on each side, then a complete logistics and transport plan?

Sincerely,
Karen

---
From: aaron.miller@shipping.com
To: karen.smith@logisticscorp.com
Subject: Re: Transport Query - Used Milkers Lydenburg to Gaborone
Timestamp: 2016-07-20 11:30
Body: Our milkers will arrive on 28 July 2016 from Cape Town to Lydenburg by ship. If you can receive these milkers by road and transport them from Lydenburg to Gaborone, Botswana, please let us know your plans and the cost of the transport.

Sincerely,
Aaron

---
From: bridget.wilson@transport.co.za
To: karen.smith@logisticscorp.com
Subject: Re: Transport Query - Used Milkers Lydenburg to Gaborone
Timestamp: 2016-07-21 10:00
Body: Yes, we can take the milkers off the ship at Lydenburg and transport them from there to Gaborone. We will use our tippers and 40ft containers for transporting these milkers. We will receive them and bring them to Gaborone where you will be able to pick them up.

Cost of transport will be:
- Lydenburg to Gaborone: R7000 per tipper
- Load, transport and discharge at Gaborone: R12,000 per container

Please let us know when you will receive the milkers on the ship in Lydenburg so that we can plan our collection.

Sincerely,
Bridget

---
From: mark.johnson@shipping.com
To: bridget.wilson@transport.co.za
Subject: Re: Transport Query - Used Milkers Lydenburg to Gaborone
Timestamp: 2016-07-22 14:00
Body: Thanks for the logistics plan. The milkers will arrive on 27 July 2016 at 09:00. The ship will berth in Lydenburg at 09:00 and will be at anchor waiting for customs clearance and other paperwork.

Also, please let us know if you want to transport these milkers from Lydenburg to Gaborone by tippers or trucks, and we will prepare an order for the milkers.

Regards,
Mark

Body: Dear Ting,

From: Guangzhou, China
Destination: Manila, Philippines
Quantity: 2,000MT (approximately 28,000 boxes, Gross 1000@1.2Tons)

Payment Terms:
- Bank Letter of Credit to Kimono Inc. (Korean Export Company)

- Sea freight: 21 days ex-work

Drew Wong

1. Letter of Credit required in favor of Hapag-Lloyd
2. All taxes, duties, and associated costs (local, state and federal) are your responsibility
3. Shipment costs including packing and insurance to be borne by your company
4. Payment due on the 10th day of the last month of every quarter
5. Shipping schedule to be coordinated between your company and Hapag-Lloyd
6. Delivery within 30 days of shipment date

Rate: USD 2,500.00 per tonne
Total for 28,000 boxes: USD 70,000

Best regards,
Ting

Email 1:
We’re thinking of shipping 9,000MT of crude oil from Jingtang to Spain. What’s your earliest availability, and how’s your rate?                    Thanks,                    Tim
Email 2:
Our rate is USD35 per MT, cargo shall load at Jingtang Oil Terminal on 12/15 Dec, ETA Spain on 17/25 Dec, you could confirm the charter today or not later than tomorrow.  Please email back your interest, thanks!

The timer I chose was 5 minutes. And the prompt was:

How did you come up with the shipping contract?

You can use PNP to shorten the time for expression. For example, to say

"we are thinking of shipping X amount of crude oil from A to B", "We'd like to buy X amount of crude oil from A to B", etc.

The PNP here is the “thinking of shipping”, “wanting to buy”, and the rest of the action words.

Since we were looking for clues on who had expressed interest in the cargo (Tim or Spain), this definitely should give you some

Q&A What’s the best time to use balticdirties?
When to use balticdirties ? Use balticdirties only if no other time charter data is available (e.g. in freight rate calculations). From: cassie.manwell@trading.com
To: j.parkin@shipping.com
Subject: LNG Freight Enquiry - US Gulf to Antwerp
Timestamp: 2023-07-01 09:30
Body: Mr. Parkin,

Can you please provide a freight estimate for 6,000MT of LNG from Mopan in the US Gulf to Antwerp in July. Is port rotation compulsory for this service?

Kind Regards,
Cassie

---
From: j.parkin@shipping.com
To: cassie.manwell@trading.com
Subject: Re: LNG Freight Enquiry - US Gulf to Antwerp
Timestamp: 2023-07-01 11:45
Body: Dear Ms. Manwell,

Thank you for your enquiry. We have prepared a proposal for the movement of 6,000MT of LNG from the US Gulf to Antwerp in July. The price can be structured in two ways:

1. Fixed FOB rate as detailed in the proposal
2. FCN basis with a CBM charge of $1.20 per CBM based on the cargo declaration

In both scenarios, the CIF rate would be fixed, with cargo delivery to the discharge port on the same day. Regarding port rotation, this would be at the shipper's request and subject to prior agreement between all parties.

Please review the proposal and return a copy of the commercial terms (either C/P or C&F).

Best regards,
James Parkin

---
From: d.smith@shipping.com
To: m.dalschaert@bimco.org
Subject: GCM/Voyage Charterparty - CBM Rate Discussion
Timestamp: 2023-07-02 14:20
Body: Dear Mr. Dalschaert,

Regarding our recent communications, our chartering division has consulted with London about the GCM/Voyage charterparty provisions (as drafted by BIMCO).

The current charterparty specifies a CBM charge of $1.20 per CBM for FCN charters. However, our client Shell has indicated they cannot proceed with this arrangement for LNG shipments unless the CBM charge is reduced to below 90 cents per CBM.

We therefore request BIMCO to consider revising the relevant provision in the GCM/Voyage Charterparty accordingly.

Best regards,
David Smith

---
From: d.smith@shipping.com
To: m.dalschaert@bimco.org
Subject: Re: GCM/Voyage Charterparty - Proposed Amendment
Timestamp: 2023-07-03 10:15
Body: Dear Mr. Dalschaert,

Following our previous communication, please find below our proposed amendment to the current GCM/Voyage charterparty draft:

18.30.1 Freight shall be calculated at 1.20/cbm based on the CBM declared by the cargo

This amendment would be effective for cargoes delivered after January 1st, 2023.

Please advise if this amendment is acceptable, and we will proceed with BIMCO accordingly.

Best regards,
David Smith

From: lewis.brereton@company.com
To: bird.sarah@shipping.com
Subject: Petcoke Cargo Inquiry - Port Elizabeth
Timestamp: 2023-10-15 09:30
Body: Greetings Mrs. Bird,

We are waiting on a number of tenders for an 8,000MT cargo of dry petcoke to Port Elizabeth. We're currently unsure if the US Gulf can produce enough tonnage to meet our requirements. Can you please provide some estimated tonnages, and inform us of any other points of origin that could be competitive?

Kind regards,
Lewis

---
From: bird.sarah@shipping.com
To: lewis.brereton@company.com
Subject: Re: Petcoke Cargo Inquiry - Port Elizabeth
Timestamp: 2023-10-15 14:45
Body: Dear Mr. Brereton,

The M/V Ostende is due to load a cargo of Petcoke from Grays Harbor and delivery is scheduled for early November. The US Gulf is the only origin that we can produce in volume. We currently expect to have sufficient petcoke available to meet all of our charterers requirements.

Please note you will need to present your documentary requirements including:
- Full set of Bills of Lading (BLs)
- Charter Party
- LPA Form 1
- Most recent IOPPCA

The US Gulf produces 3 grades of petcoke:
1. Very fine grade
2. Course grade
3. Lamellar (wax contaminated) grade

We are able to book all 3 grades of petcoke on an as-available basis.

Best regards,
Sarah Bird

---
From: shan.wei@trader.com
To: lewis.brereton@company.com
Subject: Dry Petcoke Availability Nov-Dec
Timestamp: 2023-10-16 10:15
Body: Dear Mr. Brereton,

We shall have dry petcoke available for November and December loading. We can offer about 10,000-15,000MT per load.

Please advise if you would like us to provide pricing including the cost index.

Kind regards,
Wei Shan

Timestamp: 2009-03-15 09:30
Body: Matthieu,

We'd like to ship 8,000MT of pyrophyllite ore from Aqaba to Mombasa next month. Could you let us know your best freight rate and vessel name for this shipment?

Best regards,
Ralph

---
From: matthieu.dubois@shipbroker.com
To: ralph.wilson@mineraltrade.com
Subject: Re: Freight Quote Request - Pyrophyllite Ore Aqaba to Mombasa
Timestamp: 2009-03-15 14:45
Body: Hi Ralph,

Thanks for your inquiry. We are pleased to quote for this shipment as follows:

Vessel: XING LING
Sailing from: Qingdao on or about March 28, 2009
ETA Mombasa: on or about April 11, 2009

Rates:
- US$ 200/MT for container load (FOB basis)
- US$ 180/MT for container load (CIF basis)

Above rates include:
a) Ocean freight
b) Vessel berthing at Mombasa
c) Standard port charges (clearance and handling)
d) Container costs
e) Agency fees

Please note these rates exclude:
a) Shipment costs from Suez to Qingdao
b) Origin shipment costs from Qingdao

Best regards,
Matthieu

---
From: ralph.wilson@mineraltrade.com
To: matthieu.dubois@shipbroker.com
Subject: Re: Freight Quote Request - Pyrophyllite Ore Aqaba to Mombasa
Timestamp: 2009-03-16 08:15
Body: Hi Matthieu,

Thanks for your reply. Let me clarify our requirements:

• We prefer containerized shipping to Mombasa. We can source containers in Qingdao.

• We require door-to-door service. Our agent will handle all port operations in China, inland transportation of containers to destination in Mombasa, and final delivery after discharge.

• We prefer to arrange shipment and freight payment ourselves.

• We would like this arranged on CIF basis with payment in Qingdao.

Could you please provide an updated quote based on these specifications?

Thanks,
Ralph

Email 2:
Greetings!                   My name is Mary Wells. As a financial advisor to the Wilson family, I am pleased to introduce this matter to you, especially since you have proven your ability to carry out your operations without much delay.   I wish to inform you that the personal effects of my clients, Mrs.Glenda Wilson and Mr. Michael Wilson were loaded on to your vessel named MT “” and shipped from Southampton to Monrovia, Liberia, dated 10th May 2008.  I wish to inform you that the goods which comprises of one piece of one Rolls Royce and four pieces of Household goods have been detained by the Librerian authorities for the past three years as they claim that the customs documents were not properly filled.  This has forced Mrs. Glenda and Mr. Michael Wilson to incur huge demurrage and storage fees which they cannot afford to pay now. It
Email 3:
Thanks for your email and apologies for my delay in replying. I don’t think that there is an issue with the cargo in Liberia, it is no longer onboard the vessel but I have sent you a scan of a document from the shipping line saying that they can assist with releasing the cargo. It’s my feeling that there is a bureaucratic delay in Liberia and you might have to employ a solicitor to assist, do you have any ideas about that? Best regards, Scott
Email 4:
Ah yes, that explains a lot. We’ve not got any vessels at present. Sorry.
Regards
Steve

<Email 5>:
I have some information for you regarding what I’m sure will be your next job. You need to visit Liberia. I’ve made an arrangement with the Liberia international trade and transportation secretariat to assist you with the release of the cargo.
I’ll send you a document of authority signed by the director of the importation department at the customs department of Liberia. Do you have a representative there who will be able to pick it up on your behalf? If not, let me know and I’ll contact the Liberian secretary.
Don’t worry about the rest, I’ll handle it.
Regards,
Steve

Hi Capt. Hu,                    We have 6,000 MT of iron ore to ship from Makassar to Surabaya. Please provide the best quote.                    Kind regards,                    Mr. Nguyen
Email 2:

Email 3:

I have 1,000 MT of iron ore to ship from Makassar to Surabaya. Can you quote for my cargo?
Kind regards,
Mrs. Nguyen
Email 4:
Hi Capt. Hu,
I need a quotation for the shipment of 1,000 MT of iron ore from Makassar to Surabaya.
Regards,
Mr. Nguyen

The expressions and sentences in each of the four emails are different and so the email might not be a good example of phishing attack.

(You are to decide)
=> i removed the word 4 after 1,000 MT in the email
After doing so, the two first emails have a similar structure and are difficult to distinguish.
=> Could you explain why?
=> Since 4 was removed, the emails could be written by two different persons. So 1,000 MT was not indicative of who wrote the email.
(Something related to Markov Chain and Bayesian networks is used)

• Markov Chains can be used to describe many processes in a way that enables understanding in a mathematical form.
• Markov processes
Email 5:
Hi Capt. Hu,
I have 1,000 MT of iron ore to ship from Makassar to Surabaya. Can you quote for my cargo?
Kind regards,
Mrs. Nguyen

If you click on the blue part, you get a pop-up.
The blue part is an example of something else being put on the Markov Chain.

<Email 6>:

I have 1,000 MT of iron ore to ship from Makassar to Surabaya. Can you quote for my cargo?
Kind regards,
Mrs. Nguyen

---
From: annette.smith@shipping.com
To: dan.jenks@trading.com
Subject: Re: Cereal Shipment Quote Request - NOLA to Istanbul
Timestamp: 2024-05-15 18:45
Body: Good afternoon Mr. Jenks,

We understand that you require shipping a 4,500MT shipment of cereals from New Orleans to Istanbul by 30 May. Please accept our quotation for this service at $115 per mt FOB New Orleans.

This includes our $35 per mt fuel surcharge and a $10 per mt surcharge for loading at New Orleans. Also please note that your shipment will require the following insurance cover:
- General Average
- Warranties
- Freight Risk
- War Risks

You should confirm with your insurers that the vessels you will use have the appropriate cover.

We will happily provide you with the relevant documentation for your shipment and look forward to hearing from you.

Best regards,
Annette Smith

You: Hello Sophie, can you please share the material specification? The general rule is to ask for all the details required to take an offer. This way, you will reduce the time spent on exchanges, and you will know whether you will be interested in that opportunity.

Email 4:
If you are in direct contact with the buyer, please try to get the material specification. In this case, you need to be direct and say that you cannot send a freight quotation without that document. If they ask about the freight quotation first, share a rough estimate with a mention that it will be updated when you have the material specification. The buyer should realize that this is the only way for you to take an offer. It is your first line of defense against waste of time. Other brokers might not understand that they need to ask for the material specification because they do not have a "ship" yet, so they can only discuss price and laycan. This is very wrong, but I am sure it happens.  If you are an agent, you should receive the material specification from the buyer. If you don't have it, call your counterpart to discuss this. Dear Geraldine,                    We’d like to cargo 300MT of caprolactum from Cotonou to Dover. Email 2:
Thanks Pauline,

I checked the schedules and I think you mean the Commodore. This is our weekly spot cargo service, loading containers for France.

The Commodore berths at the South Container Terminal but we can't berth there this week. There are no slots available and the berths have to be occupied in a particular order.

South Container Terminal berths are occupied in this order:
5, 1, 2, 4, 7, 3, 6

This week we have the Commodore coming in from Kingston on Wednesday. This is the first available berth for that vessel so we are expecting her to be berthed at 6 South. The ship is due to sail to Cherbourg on Friday night.

Geraldine

Email 1:
Could you give us the best rates for 150MT shipment of steam coal to Tocopilla, Chile? Please send us a complete quotation including all freight, brokerage, storage and other relevant charges.                                        Jon
Email 2:
My name is Duglas Brown, director of Romco Mining Ltd. Romco is involved in the mining and export of several types of coal from different regions of the world. Our requirements for steam coal are as follows:
Coal – Sulphur 1.5% max
Calorific Value – 6,000 kcal/kg min
Ash Content – 15% max
Moisture Content – 5% max
Volatile Matter – 23% max
Other Minerals – 18% max
Fines – 5% max
With quality standards like this, I can assure you that you will have no problem in selling the coal from your mine at any market in the world, providing the price is competitive. You can send us the price for your coal per ton CIF to the port of Antofagasta. We will review it and get back to you.

We look forward to seeing your offers at any time. In the meantime, we’d like to invite you to have a look at our website. You can find many details there about our company, our subsidiaries and our staff. In fact, our website has been recently updated and optimized to look very nice on mobile phones.

Ron Skye

I especially like the Product section where all the data regarding our coal quality can be found, the Quality section with all the standards we are ready to meet, the Health and Safety section and the Environment section. You clearly make a very important effort to improve the conditions of workers and to ensure the safety of your operations, and we strongly share these goals. The Visual Tour is very nice too, and I particularly appreciated the mine and the processing plants pictures.

Moreover, we’d like to ask a favor: could you please send us the prices and the complete specifications of your product?

Ron Skye

input_text:
Email 1:
Hello Mr. Batra,                    We expect to ship 3,000MT of motors from Singapore to Colombo by April 1st. Would your vessel be available for a short term voyage, and are you flexible on ballast condition?                    Best regards,                    Ernest
Email 2:
Dear Mr. Ernest,
                    The "Coastline" is currently berthed at Kakinada on Indian coast and I expect to receive her draft survey report on or about the 25th. Her charterers are currently assessing the bunkers required by the vessel for Singapore, however, we may be able to depart the previous fixture for Singapore as early as the 26th March.
                    As far as ballast conditions are concerned, your charterers could also try "Coastline's" current charterers (i.e. "Sambalino" of the same owners) as they will be arriving from a short haul fixture at the moment and may be in a position to proceed immediately to the loading port in ballast. Alternatively, you may wish to proceed ballast and obtain fuel in advance of loading.
                    Any more information you require please feel free to contact me on the below
Email 3:
Hi Mr. Batra,
                    May I request you to assist us in exploring with your owners the following options for our shipment as below:

1. Send the "Coastline" from Kakinada to your discharge port to arrive in 6 days time;
2. Send the "Coastline" from Kakinada to your discharge port to arrive in 10 days time;
3. Send the "Sambalino" from your discharge port to the Singapore loading port to arrive in 6 days time;
4. Send the "Sambalino" from your discharge port to the Singapore loading port to arrive in 10 days time;

                    As soon as the draft survey is received, I will forward you a copy with the same. In the meantime, if you require further information, please feel free to contact me on the below.

                    Thanks,
                    Ernest
Email 4:
Dear Mr. Batra,
                    Thank you for sending the Sambalino draft survey. I am pleased to inform you that Sambalino would arrive in 6 days. Please revert for futher details. We are expecting to send the draft survey of the Coastline shortly.
                    Best regards,
                    Ernest
